revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Abigail Kuaihelani Campbell |image = Abigail Kuaihelani Campbell.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1858|8|22|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[Lahaina]], [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1908|11|1|1858|8|22|mf=yes}} |death_place = [[Honolulu]], [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] |spouse = [[James Campbell (industrialist)|James Campbell]]
[[Samuel Parker (Hawaii)|Samuel Parker]] |children = [[Abigail Campbell Kawānanakoa]] + others |parents = John Maipinepine Bright
Mary Kamai Hanaike |occupation = Political leader |nationality = [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] |signature = Kuaihelani Campbell 1898 signature.jpg }} '''Abigail Kuaihelani Maipinepine Bright, Mrs. Campbell''' (August 22, 1858 – November 1, 1908) was a member of the nobility of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. During her life, she married two powerful businessmen, particularly adding to the success of her first husband, [[James Campbell (industrialist)|James Campbell]], and giving him descendants. Among their grandchildren were three heirs to the throne of the kingdom of Hawaii. ==Life== Abigail Kuaihelani Maipinepine Bright was born on August 22, 1858, on [[Lahaina]], [[Maui]].{{cite news |title= Death of Mrs. Campbell-Parker at the Hospital |newspaper= Hawaiian Gazette |location= Honolulu |date=November 8, 1908 |page= 1 |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1907-10-08/ed-1/seq-1/ |accessdate=April 22, 2012 }}{{cite news|hdl=10524/354|title=Princess Abigail Kawananakoa: the Forgotten Territorial Native Hawaiian Leader|work=Hawaiian Journal of History|publisher=Hawaii Historical Society|volume=37|author=Richard A. Hawkins|year=2003|pages=163–77}} Her mother was Mary Kamai Hanaike and her father was John Maipinepine Bright.{{cite web|title=Abigail Kuaihelani Maipinepine |work=Our Family History and Ancestry |publisher=Families of Old Hawaii |url=http://familiesofoldhawaii.com/getperson.php?personID=I4539&tree=Ano |accessdate=2010-03-25 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} She is descended from the Kalanikini line of Maui chieftains, with some European-American ancestry on her father's side.{{cite news|title=The Story of Maui Royalty: Lunaliloʻs Dynasty Is Represented By Amalus|author=Kapikauinamoku|newspaper=[[The Honolulu Advertiser]]|date=December 11, 1955|url=http://ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?e=q-0somr-000Sec--11en---8&a=d&d=D0.6.2&toc=0}} [[File:Abigail Campbell and family.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Abigail and daughters.]] [[File:Hui Aloha ʻĀina o Na Wahine.jpg|150px|thumb|left|The Hui Aloha ʻĀina o Na Wahine.]] On October 30, 1877, she married [[Scotch-Irish American]] businessman [[James Campbell (industrialist)|James Campbell]] (1826–1900), who became one of the largest landowners in the islands.{{cite web|url=http://www.ulukau.org/gsdl2.7/cgi-bin/algene?a=d&d=D09-000038|title=Marriage record, Oahu(1832–1910)|work=state archives digital collections|publisher=state of Hawaii|accessdate= 2010-03-01}} Their children were Margaret (1880–1882); Abigail (1882–1945), who became better-known as [[Abigail Campbell Kawānanakoa]] after marrying a Hawaiian prince; Alice Kamokilaikawai (1884–1971) (see Alice Campbell); James, Jr. (1886–1889); Muriel (Mrs. Robert K.) Shingle (1890–1951); Royalist (1893–1896); and Beatrice (Mrs. Francis) Wrigley.{{cite book |title= Notable Women of Hawaii |year=1984 |publisher=University of Hawaii Press |author= Barbara Bennett Peterson |isbn =0-8248-0820-7 |page= 209|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rFevAAAAIAAJ }} Daughter Alice Kamokila Campbell became active in the anti-statehood movement after the United States annexed Hawai{{okina}}i, making it a Territory.{{cite news|hdl=10524/218|title=Anti-Statehood Movement and the Legacy of Alice Kamokila Campbell|work=Hawaiian Journal of History|publisher=Hawaii Historical Society|volume=27|author=John S. Whitehead|year=1993|pages=43–63}} Daughter Margaret, son James Campbell, Jr. and two other daughters died young.{{cite web|title=James Campbell, Esq. |publisher=James Campbell Company LLC |year=2003 |url=http://www.kapolei.com/pdf/jcbookletPDFoptimized.pdf |accessdate=2010-03-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090411090013/http://www.kapolei.com/pdf/jcbookletPDFoptimized.pdf |archivedate=2009-04-11 }} James Campbell, Sr. died in 1900 and bequeathed his widow one-third of the estate during her lifetime. After the 1893 [[overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]], Abigail Campbell and Emma Nāwahī, wife of [[Joseph Nāwahī]], became leaders of the Hawaiian native movement for protesting the takeover, called ''Hui Hawai{{okina}}i Aloha {{okina}}Āina o Na Wahine'' (Hawaiian Women's Patriot League).{{cite book|author=Noenoe K. Silva|title=Aloha betrayed: Native Hawaiian Resistance to American Colonialism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-G4TZ_hDVfsC&pg=PA130|year=2004|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=978-0-8223-3349-4|page=130}} She became its president. On January 4, 1902, widow Abigail Kuaihelani Campbell married widower [[Samuel Parker (Hawaii)|Samuel Parker]], half owner of [[Parker Ranch]].{{cite news|title=A day's weddings|date=January 5, 1902|newspaper= [[The New York Times]]|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1902/01/05/118465167.pdf|accessdate=2010-03-25}} They had a private ceremony in the Occidental Hotel of [[San Francisco]] with a judge presiding. The Campbell estate owned the St. James Hotel in [[San Jose, California]]. At the time, Abigail Campbell was also preparing to celebrate the wedding of her daughter Abigail to Prince [[David Kawānanakoa]], which took place two days later. The Parkers traveled to [[Washington, D.C.]].{{cite news|title=San Jose Lady has a Responsible Position in Prospect|newspaper=The Evening News|location=San Jose, California|date=January 31, 1902|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jSsiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OKQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2837%2C1113342|accessdate=2010-03-25}} They returned to California February 2, 1902; it was rumored that Parker would be appointed as the next governor of the [[Territory of Hawaii]].{{cite news|title=Prince David and His Bride Are En Route to Island Home|newspaper=The Evening News|location=San Jose, California|date=February 1, 1902|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jisiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OKQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3189%2C1214078|accessdate= 2010-03-25}} [[George R. Carter]] was appointed instead. They had no children. Campbell-Parker died November 1, 1908, after surgery for breast cancer.{{cite news|title= Death of Mrs. Campbell-Parker at the Hospital|newspaper=Hawaiian Gazette|date=November 3, 1908|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1908-11-03/ed-1/seq-3|accessdate=June 13, 2010}} (reprinted from Honolulu Advertiser) ==Family tree== {{Kawānanakoa family tree}} ==References== {{Commons category|Abigail Kuaihelani Campbell}} {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Campbell, Abigail Kuaihelani}} [[Category:1858 births]] [[Category:1908 deaths]] [[Category:Native Hawaiian people]] [[Category:Hawaiian nobility]] [[Category:Deaths from breast cancer]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Hawaii]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.4beta3)
revision.text:
'''Abu Mu'az al-Jeddawi''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: ), a [[Saudi]] who reportedly lived in Yemen, is believed to have been rendered by the [[CIA]] to [[Jordan]] in early 2002. His real name is believed to be Ahmad Ibrahim Abu al-Hasana.
Al-Jeddawi was listed by the FBI as a wanted terrorism suspect in February 2002. He was identified as a known associate of a Yemeni Al Qaeda leader named [[Fawaz Yahya al-Rabeei]].
==February 12, 2002 terror alert== In early 2002, according to an FBI report, as a result of US military operations in [[Afghanistan]] and of on-going interviews of detainees in [[Guantanamo Bay, Cuba]], information became available on February 11, 2002 regarding threats to US interests which indicated that a planned attack may have been about to occur in the United States or against US interests in the country of Yemen on or around the next day, February 12, 2002.<ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/mostwant/seekinfo/2-11-02.htm FBI Most Wanted Terrorists Seeking Information 2-11-02] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020605061032/http://www.fbi.gov/mostwant/seekinfo/2-11-02.htm |date=2002-06-05 }}, (dead link)</ref>
In response, on February 11, 2002, the FBI listed Abu Mu'az al-Jeddawi and 16 other suspected terrorists to the [[FBI Seeking Information - War on Terrorism list]]. The early version of that list was then known as the "Most Wanted Terrorists Seeking Information" list. Years later, the FBI removed his profile from the main page of that list.
On February 14, 2002, several days after the FBI alert, six of the names were removed from the list, and the FBI re-published the list with only eleven names and photos. Six of the suspects who had been named were already in custody.<ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/mostwant/seekinfo/2-14-02.htm FBI Most Wanted Terrorists Seeking Information 2-14-02] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020610170928/http://www.fbi.gov/mostwant/seekinfo/2-14-02.htm |date=2002-06-10 }}, revision by FBI removed 6 Yemen prisoners' names from the list (dead link)</ref>
The six names identified in the Yemen plot on February 11, 2002, but who were removed from the list on February 14, 2002, are: [[Issam Ahmad Dibwan al-Makhlafi]], [[Ahmad al-Akhader Nasser Albidani]], [[Bashir Ali Nasser al-Sharari]], [[Abdulaziz Muhammad Saleh bin Otash]], [[Shuhour Abdullah Mukbil al-Sabri]] and Riyadh Shikawi.
'''Abu Mu'az al-Jeddawi''' remained listed among the eleven names still being sought on February 14, 2002. The others who also remained were: Fawaz Yahya al-Rabeei, [[Omar Ahmad Omar al-Hubishi]], [[Ammar Abadah Nasser al-Wa'eli]], [[Alyan Muhammad Ali al-Wa'eli]], [[Bassam Abdullah bin Bushar al-Nahdi]], [[Mustafa Abdulkader Aabed al-Ansari]], [[Samir Abduh Sa'id al-Maktawi]], [[Abdulrab Muhammad Muhammad Ali al-Sayfi]], [[Abu Nasr al-Tunisi]] and [[Amin Saad Muhammad al-Zumari]].
Whether foiled, aborted, or merely incorrect specific intelligence, the February 12, 2002 attack never occurred.
==CIA Rendition to Jordan==
Human Rights Watch has reported that al-Jeddawi was rendered by the CIA to Amman, Jordan, in early 2002, where he was held in the custody of the Jordan's General Intelligence Department (GID).<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/en/node/62263/section/5 Human Rights Watch, Double Jeopardy: CIA Rendition to Jordan (2008)]</ref> Human Rights Watch researchers spoke to two former detainees held by the GID who said that they communicated with al-Jeddawi while he was detained at the GID detention facility in late 2002; a third former detainee wrote that he saw al-Jeddawi there, too.
Human Rights Watch's sources differ regarding where al-Jeddawi was arrested. Both al-Tabuki and another person claim that al-Jeddawi was arrested in [[Yemen]]. Al-Tabuki said that he was arrested less than a month after his wedding. A third source, however, who was also held in GID custody with al-Jeddawi, believes that al-Jeddawi was arrested in Kuwait, although he was not certain about this point. All of them agree, at any rate, that al-Jeddawi was in US custody prior to being handed over to Jordan. And according to one source, a US agent "hit him in the head."
One person, who told Human Rights Watch that al-Jeddawi was "famous in Afghanistan," said:
<small>He was a really rich guy, and he lived in [[Yemen]]; he was married to a Yemeni woman. The Yemenis arrested him and handed him over to the US. I actually saw him in GID: we met in the bathroom thanks to the help of a nice soldier.</small>
This same informant not only saw al-Jeddawi in custody in late 2002 but also communicated with al-Jeddawi's family later. He said that the family told him that al-Jeddawi was held at the GID facility for more than a year, during which time he was kept hidden from the ICRC. Al-Jeddawi is believed to be currently incarcerated in Saudi Arabia.
==See also== [[Extraordinary rendition]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[https://www.hrw.org/en/node/62263/section/5 Human Rights Watch, Double Jeopardy: CIA Rendition to Jordan (2008)]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Jeddawi, Abu}} [[Category:Saudi Arabian people]] [[Category:People subject to extraordinary rendition by the United States|Al-Jeddawi, Abu Mu'az]] [[Category:Living people]]
