revision.text:
{{Infobox character | colour = #FF8000 | image = Alex Vause.jpg | caption = Laura Prepon as Alex Vause | name = Alex Vause | portrayer = [[Laura Prepon]]
Rachel Resheff (at age 10) | series = [[Orange Is the New Black]] | first = "[[Orange Is the New Black (season 1)#ep1|I Wasn't Ready]]" (1.01)
July 11, 2013 | alias = | creator = | occupation = | significantother = [[Piper Chapman]] (wife)
Sylvia (ex-girlfriend) | lbl21 = Parents | data21 = Diane Vause (mother)
Lee Burley (father) }} '''Alex Vause''' is a fictional character played by [[Laura Prepon]] on the [[Netflix]] series ''[[Orange Is the New Black]]''. The character is loosely based on the real ex-girlfriend of [[Piper Kerman]], author of ''[[Orange Is the New Black: My Year in a Women's Prison]]''. Before her arrest, Vause worked for an international drug cartel and was in a relationship with protagonist [[Piper Chapman]], who once transported drug money for her during their travels. Vause is portrayed as the catalyst for Chapman's [[indictment]]. She is reunited with her ex-lover in federal prison, nearly a decade after the events that led to their breakup. Her relationship with Chapman is reignited, as they carry out a tumultuous love affair in prison. Vause is noted for her pragmatism, forthrightness, wit and veiled vulnerability. She is a main character in seasons one, three, four, five, and six and a recurring character in season two. ==Inspiration== The character of Alex Vause is loosely based on Catherine Cleary Wolters, ex-girlfriend of [[Piper Kerman]], the author of ''[[Orange Is the New Black: My Year in a Women's Prison]]'' and an executive consultant on the series.{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2014/04/orange-is-the-new-black-real-alex|title=The Real Alex of Orange Is the New Black Speaks for the First Time: "I Was Not Piper's First, and I Certainly Did Not Seduce Her"|website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|first=Sue|last=Carswell|date=April 15, 2014|accessdate=June 4, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/orange-new-black-author-hints-new-season-talks-reform-way-stl#stream/0|title='Orange Is the New Black' Author Hints At New Season, Talks Reform, On Way To STL|first=Nancy|last=Fowler|publisher=[[St. Louis Public Radio]]|date=September 1, 2014|accessdate=June 4, 2017}} In Kerman's memoir, Wolters is given the pseudonym Nora Jansen, who is a marginal character in the book.{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2015/05/10/real-life-alex-on-oitnb-feared-show-would-ruin-her-life/|title=Real-life Alex on 'OITNB' feared show would ruin her life|last=Callahan|first=Maureen|date=May 10, 2015|website=[[New York Post]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} In actuality, Kerman and Wolters did not serve their prison sentences together as depicted in the series however they were reunited in a flight to [[Chicago]], where they were detained for several weeks [[Metropolitan Correctional Center, Chicago|in a detention facility]] to testify in the drug trafficking case.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/tv/article/Orange-is-the-New-Black-author-and-husband-tell-5647662.php|title='Orange Is the New Black' TV series reflects couple's reality|website=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|first=Meredith|last=May|date=July 27, 2014|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Their stint in Chicago is portrayed in the series' second season; however, the defendant they were to testify against was changed to the cartel's kingpin, as was the fact that Wolters and Kerman were cell-mates in the prison.{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/us/tv/orange-is-the-new-black/247386/orange-is-the-new-black-how-the-book-adds-to-the-show|title=Orange Is the New Black: How the Book Adds to the Show|website=[[Den of Geek]]|first=Abigail|last=Brady|date=July 2, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lstylegstyle.com/stories/the-real-piper-of-orange-is-the-new-black/|title=The Real Piper of Orange is the New Black|website=L Style G Style|first=Lynn|last=Yeldell|date=May 8, 2014|accessdate=June 5, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170617151356/http://www.lstylegstyle.com/stories/the-real-piper-of-orange-is-the-new-black/|archive-date=2017-06-17|dead-url=yes|df=}} Wolters met Kerman in 1991 in [[Northampton, Massachusetts]], becoming friends around the time Kerman graduated from [[Smith College]]. Kerman wrote in her memoir that Wolters was part of a "clique of impossibly stylish and cool lesbians in their mid-30s".{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/08/12/211339427/behind-the-new-black-the-real-pipers-prison-story|title=Behind 'The New Black': The Real Piper's Prison Story|website=[[NPR]]|date=August 12, 2013|accessdate=June 4, 2017}} Wolters said both of them ran in "the same little [[Northampton, Massachusetts|Noho]] lesbian social circle", and spent time together when she returned from her travels. Wolters had told Kerman she worked for an African drug lord, moving heroin around internationally, while Kerman was fascinated by her globe-trotting, adventurous lifestyle.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-11-14/news/ct-met-orange-new-black-20131114_1_piper-kerman-piper-chapman-drug-case|title='Orange is New Black' drug case still open in Chicago federal court|website=[[Chicago Tribune]]|first=David|last=Heinzmann|date=November 14, 2013|accessdate=June 5, 2017}}{{cite book|title=Orange Is the New Black: My Year in a Women's Prison|author=Kerman, Piper|year=2010|publisher=[[Spiegel & Grau]]|isbn=978-0-812-98618-1}} Wolters asked Kerman if she wanted to take part in the operation. According to Wolters, she and Kerman became romantically involved after Kerman had gotten involved in the drug ring. In her interview with ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', Wolters said that they were not girlfriends but friends with benefits, a notion with which Kerman disagreed, stating that they may have different perspectives about their time together and their relationship was complicated. Kerman traveled with Wolters to exotic places, and made several trips carrying drug-funds for the cartel. Kerman realized she needed to walk away when Wolters asked her to transport heroin instead of money, after which she flew home and started a new life.{{cite web|url=https://www.autostraddle.com/meet-the-real-alex-vause-catherine-cleary-wolters-has-mixed-feelings-about-orange-is-the-new-black/|title=Meet The Real Alex Vause: Catherine Cleary Wolters Has Mixed Feelings About "Orange Is The New Black"|website=[[Autostraddle]]|author=Riese|date=April 15, 2014|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Years later, Kerman was indicted and plead guilty to a money laundering charge, serving 13 months in [[Federal Correctional Institution, Danbury|a minimum-security prison in Danbury, Connecticut]]. Wolters was charged with conspiracy to import heroin, serving nearly six years in [[Federal Correctional Institution, Dublin |a Dublin, California prison]], and nearly 14 years on parole. In the series, the issue of whether Vause implicated Chapman and the effect on their personal relationship is a major plot line of the first season. When Wolters and others involved in the drug ring were arrested by federal law enforcement, Wolters said that she, like the others, named everyone involved, including Kerman. Wolters also stated that, contrary to Kerman's implication in her memoir, she was not "singularly responsible for [her] downfall", as she was honest about what she did and getting involved was Kerman's decision.{{cite news|url=http://people.com/crime/cleary-wolters-meet-the-woman-who-inspired-alex-vause-orange-is-the-new-black/|title=Meet the Real-Life Alex Vause of Orange Is the New Black|last=Truesdell|first=Jeff|date=June 5, 2015|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Although Kerman aimed to take responsibility for her actions, she said she still carried some resentment toward Wolters [for naming her], later making peace with her when they were held together in a Chicago facility. Unlike in the series, Wolters and Kerman did not get back together when they were reunited in prison. According to Wolters, "the only [physical] similarity between myself and [Vause] is my black glasses." In her memoir, Kerman described Wolters as a "droll" woman, with a "drawling, wisecracking husky voice" and a "playful, watchful way of drawing a person out"; "when she paid you attention, it felt as if she were about to let you in on a private joke." Wolters' interview to ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' in April 2014 led to a book deal for her memoir.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/07/cleary-wolters-out-of-orange_n_7226614.html|title=Cleary Wolters, The Real Alex Vause, Shares Her Story For The First Time|website=[[HuffPost]]|first=Erin|last=Whitney|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} In 2015, [[HarperOne]] released ''Out of Orange'', Wolters' memoir covering from the circumstances of her involvement in the drug trafficking ring and her relationship with Kerman, to her arrest, prison experience, and the present.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/real-life-alex-vause-orange-new-black-328552|title=Q&A: The Real-Life Alex Vause Discusses Prison, Memoir 'Out of Orange'|last=Mejia|first=Paula|date=July 5, 2015|work=[[Newsweek]]|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/orange-is-new-black-character-725795|title=The Real Alex From 'Orange Is the New Black' Is Getting Her Own Book|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Hillary|last=Lewis|date=August 15, 2014|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} ==Storylines== {{update|section|date=September 2017}} ===Season 1=== Vause is introduced in the first episode through flashbacks; she and Chapman were both involved in crimes involving [[drug money]]. At the end of the first episode, the audience sees that Vause and Chapman are both serving their sentences in the same prison, Litchfield Penitentiary.{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/orange-new-black-season-1-recap-everything-know-season-2-premiere-1593957|title='Orange Is The New Black' Season 1 Recap: Everything To Know Before The Season 2 Premiere|last=Schaefer|first=Megan|date=June 3, 2014|work=[[International Business Times]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} The two begin a romantic and sexual relationship in episode six; they are also both involved in a dispute with another inmate, [[Tiffany Doggett|Tiffany "Pennsatucky" Doggett]] ([[Taryn Manning]]), who locks Vause in a dryer and then attempts to kill Chapman in the season finale. Vause was raised solely by her mother and, in the ninth episode 'Fucksgiving', Vause's father is seen to be an influence on her being involved in the drug cartel.{{cite news|url=http://www.thewire.com/entertainment/2014/06/your-guide-to-catching-up-to-orange-is-the-new-black-in-time-for-season-two/372080/|title=Your Guide to Catching Up to 'Orange Is the New Black' in Time for Season Two|last=Reid|first=Joe|date=June 3, 2014|work=The Wire|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} When Chapman realises that Vause was the one who told authorities about her illegal drug activities, they break off their relationship. Vause then becomes sexually involved with another inmate, [[Nicky Nichols]] ([[Natasha Lyonne]]).{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/08/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-1-finale.html|title=Orange Is the New Black Season 1 Finale Recap: I Saw the Light|last=Henderson|first=Danielle|date=August 29, 2013|work=Vulture|accessdate=August 23, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.afterellen.com/tv/191973-orange-is-the-new-black-recap-1-13-cant-fix-crazy/3|title="Orange is the New Black" recap (1.13): Can’t Fix Crazy|last=Davis|first=Ali|date=July 25, 2013|work=After Ellen|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} ===Season 2=== In the first episode, Vause promises Chapman that she will lie to protect her in the upcoming trial of her former boss [[Kubra Balik]]. She breaks this promise, however, and, after testifying against Balik, Vause manages to secure release from prison while Chapman remains incarcerated.{{cite news|url=http://www.afterellen.com/tv/218712-orange-is-the-new-black-recap-2-1-thirsty-bird/3|title="Orange is the New Black" recap (2.1): Thirsty Bird|last=Piccoli|first=Dana|date=June 6, 2014|work=After Ellen|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} After discovering that Balik was not imprisoned for his crimes, Vause fears for her life; she is also unable to leave her apartment due to the terms of her parole.{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/06/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-2-episode-11-hunger-strike.html|title=Orange Is the New Black Season 2, Episode 11 Recap: How About I Kill the Bitch?|last=Henderson|first=Danielle|date=June 18, 2014|work=Vulture|accessdate=August 23, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/11/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-go-ahead-girls-take-a-break-from-your-values/|title=‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: ‘Go Ahead, Girls, Take a Break From Your Values’|last=Zernike|first=Kate|date=July 11, 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} She visits Chapman in prison and confides in her that she is scared; Chapman then gets Bloom to tell Vause's parole officer that Vause is breaking her parole, which lands her back in prison, where she is safe from Balik's retribution. ===Season 3=== Vause appears in every episode of the third season. Chapman reports Vause to a parole officer and she is sent back to Litchfield prison; Chapman does eventually admit to doing this and the two begin frequently having [[hate sex]].{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/ustv/s245/orange-is-the-new-black/review/a651710/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-review-episodes-1-3-blend-comedy-and-tragedy.html|title=Orange is the New Black season 3 review: Episodes 1-3 blend comedy and tragedy|last=Dibdin|first=Emma|date=June 12, 2015|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2015/06/orange-is-the-new-black-review-mothers-daybed-bugs.html|title= Orange is the New Black Review: "Mother’s Day"/"Bed Bugs and Beyond"|last=Amatangelo|first=Amy|date=June 14, 2015|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} Chapman and Vause reconcile and officially resume their relationship, but become more distant again as the season progresses; Chapman becomes romantically involved with a new inmate, [[Stella Carlin]] ([[Ruby Rose]]), and this upsets Vause.{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/recap/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-10/2|title= A Tittin' and a Hairin|last=Dornbush|first=Jonathon|date=June 17, 2015|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.afterellen.com/tv/441075-orange-new-black-recap-3-10-tittin-hairin|title= "Orange is the New Black" recap (3.10): A Tittin’ and a Hairin’|last=Steiner|first=Chelsea|date=July 8, 2015|work=After Ellen|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} Vause becomes increasingly concerned that Balik has sent someone into the prison to spy on her and bring her harm; she suspects that this person is [[Lolly Whitehill]] ([[Lori Petty]]) and attacks her in the toilet. It turns out that Whitehill is completely delusional and thinks that Vause is from the [[National Security Agency]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/recap/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-8|title= 'Fear, and Other Smells'|last=Dornbush|first=Jonathon|date=June 15, 2015|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://entertainthis.usatoday.com/2015/06/13/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-3-episode-10-a-tittin-a-hairin/|title='Orange is the New Black' binge recap: It's not all fun and games|last=Lawler|first=Kelly|date=June 13, 2015|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} In the season finale, Vause is confronted by Balik's henchman [[Aydin Bayat]] and her fate is left ambiguous.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/8-questions-orange-is-new-806693|title=8 Questions 'Orange Is the New Black' Left Unanswered at the End of Season 3|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Rick|last=Porter|date=July 3, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} === Season 4 === In the first episode, Vause is seen being strangled by Aydin Bayat in the greenhouse, struggling for her life. She is saved by Lolly Whitehill who kicks him seemingly to death. However, Vause discovers in the night that he is just barely alive and is forced to suffocate him{{Cite news|url=https://tvline.com/2016/06/17/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-4-premiere-alex-lolly-kill-hitman/|title=Orange Is the New Black Season 4 Premiere Recap: Intro to Gardening|last=Schwartz|first=Ryan|date=2016-06-17|work=TVLine|access-date=2018-08-02|language=en-US}}. Vause and Whitehill, planning on burying Aydin under the floorboards, discover [[List of Orange Is the New Black characters|Frieda Berlin]], who has found the body in its temporary hiding place. Together Vause, Whitehill, and Berlin dismember and bury the body in the garden{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-episode-1/|title=‘Orange is the New Black’ Recap: Episode 1|date=2016-06-19|work=Observer|access-date=2018-08-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/film-tv/a17839/best-tv-shows-2016/|title=The 18 Best TV Shows of 2016|date=2016-12-14|work=Harper's BAZAAR|access-date=2018-08-02|language=en-US}}. As the season progresses, Whitehill becomes increasingly at risk of blowing their cover {{Cite news|url=https://www.tvguide.com/news/orange-is-the-new-black-season-4-spoilers-alex-vause/|title=Orange Is the New Black Mega Buzz: Alex Forms an Unlikely Alliance to Survive {{!}} TV Guide|date=2016-06-09|work=TVGuide.com|access-date=2018-08-02|language=en}}. Meanwhile, Vause is suffering from guilt and lives in constant fear of being caught{{Cite news|url=https://www.tvguide.com/news/orange-is-the-new-black-season-4/|title=Orange Is the New Black: Everything You Need to Know About Season 4 {{!}} TV Guide|date=2016-06-13|work=TVGuide.com|access-date=2018-08-02|language=en}}. When Berlin suggests poisoning Whitehill, Vause confides in [[Galina Reznikov|Galina "Red" Reznikov]], hoping she will convince Berlin otherwise. In episode 8, Vause and Chapman bond again while getting high with Nichols in the garden, and their relationship once again progresses. Aydin's body is found in an unwarranted investigation by [[List of Orange Is the New Black characters|Desi Piscatella]] {{Cite news|url=https://uproxx.com/sepinwall/orange-is-the-new-black-reviewing-every-season-4-episode/|title=‘Orange Is the New Black’: Reviewing every season 4 episode|date=2016-06-19|work=UPROXX|access-date=2018-08-02|language=en-US}}, resulting in Whitehill being sent to psych. Vause is never questioned about his murder. Vause's guilt manifests itself in notes left around the prison, revealing Aydin's name. Chapman convinces Vause to find them all, and prepares to burn them. ==Critical commentary== Matthew Wolfson of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' described Vause as intelligent, "with the instincts of a pragmatist, but without a strategy—a striking and emotionally direct person who may have closed off too many options for a workable future”.{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/tv/review/orange-is-the-new-black-season-one|title=Orange Is the New Black: Season One|accessdate=April 30, 2017|date=July 16, 2013|website=[[Slant Magazine]]|author=Wolfson, Matthew}} Dana Poccoli of ''[[AfterEllen]]'' said that Vause could be considered a villain in the first season as she is the reason Chapman is in prison, but she is also a "fascinating character that we want to understand and spend time with."{{cite web|url=http://www.afterellen.com/tv/214952-the-return-of-the-lesbian-villain|title=The Return of the Lesbian Villain|first=Dana|last=Piccoli|website=[[AfterEllen]]|date=April 10, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Writing in ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', Victoria Kezra similarly suggested that before the audience meets her, Vause is already a villain, for she is "responsible for Chapman’s illegal activities" and named her ex-lover to receive less prison time. What is "wonderful" about the character, Kezra added, is that the audience's "perception of her changes throughout the show", from a villainous figure to a sympathetic individual. She observed that Vause has "a great sense of humor about the whole situation" and is "pretty caring and insightful".{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/orange-is-the-new-black-the-daily-beast-staff-debates-whos-the-best-character|title='Orange Is the New Black': The Daily Beast Staff Debates Who's the Best Character|first=Victoria|last=Kezra|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} ''[[TV Guide]]''{{'}}s Liz Raftery considered Vause a polarizing character, asking "is she a master manipulator or just misunderstood?". She proposed that Vause "seems to think of herself as a bad person but maybe she isn't, whereas [Chapman] is so convinced that she's a good person and is totally taken aback whenever anyone challenges that."{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/laura-prepon-orange-is-the-new-black-alex-piper-1069067/|title=Orange Is the New Black's Laura Prepon: "Piper Is Just as Toxic as Alex|accessdate=April 30, 2017|date=August 11, 2013|website=[[TV Guide]]|author=Raftery, Liz}} Gerri Mahn of ''[[Den of Geek]]'' wrote that unlike Chapman, Vause "doesn’t harbor any illusions about who she is or what playing by the rules will get her". Vause had named Chapman in her trial both to receive a lighter sentence and out of resentment from Chapman breaking her heart years earlier; she sincerely loves Chapman, Mahn considered, and "continually came to her defense throughout season one", turning her down when she realized Chapman was using her as "someone to fall back on when Larry doesn’t come through".{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/us/tv/orange-is-the-new-black/236206/orange-is-the-new-black-what-we-expect-in-season-two|title=Orange Is The New Black: What We Expect in Season Two|first=Gerri|last=Mahn|website=[[Den of Geek]]|date=June 6, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Tim Surette of [[TV.com]] said that Vause's season one flashbacks fit the character well, and "instantly gave us a story to be interested in", as they provided a more rounded view of the character than Chapman's purview allowed.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/orange-is-the-new-black/community/post/orange-is-the-new-black-moscow-mulefcksgiving-review-the-shu-doesnt-fit-137546438918/|title=Orange Is the New Black "Moscow Mule"/"F*cksgiving" Review: The SHU Doesn't Fit|website=[[TV.com]]|date=August 7, 2013|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} J.M Suarez wrote in ''[[PopMatters]]'' that the character of Vause is "fearless and intimidating" as well as street-smart, contrary to Chapman who is "sheltered" and "often afraid and deferential", and it is "in highlighting these differences in prison, that their eventual backstories have even more impact."{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/181721-orange-is-the-new-black-season-one-blu-ray|title='Orange is the New Black' Eases Us All Into Prison Life|website=[[PopMatters]]|first=J.M.|last=Suarez|date=May 12, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Greco Patti of ''[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]'' complimented Prepon's "nuanced" portrayal, and noted that, notwithstanding Vause's illicit occupation and her role in Chapman's imprisonment, she is a woman who "came from nothing, who loved and lost, and who maybe got used", and she seems more loyal and genuine in her love for Chapman.{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/08/laura-prepon-on-the-mystery-of-real-life-alex.html#|title=OITNB's Laura Prepon on Dancing to 'Milkshake,' Singing Meatloaf, and the Mystery of Real-Life Alex|first=Patti|last=Greco|date=August 16, 2013|website=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} ''[[The A.V. Club]]''{{'}}s Myles McNutt considered Vause's relationship with her crimes to be "complicated"; he appreciates when the show does not filter character development solely through Chapman, deeming it "productive" when Vause had "a chance to open up to [[Nicky Nichols|Nicky [Nichols]]]”.{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/orange-is-the-new-black-orange-is-the-new-black-100206|title=Orange Is The New Black: "Lesbian Request Denied"/"Imaginary Enemies|first=Myles|last=McNuutt|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=July 18, 2013|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} McNutt also said that Vause's conflict with [[Tiffany Doggett|Doggett]], who saw her as "coming from privilege", is meaningful for Vause as it is a trigger for her "past struggles with class hierarchies". According to McNutt, Vause's despondency regarding her absent father "could either gain [her] new perspective and put her life on the right track or [she could] try to fill the absence as quickly as possible", the latter of which she chose.{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/orange-is-the-new-black-the-complete-first-season-100992|title=Orange Is The New Black: "Fucksgiving"/"Bora Bora Bora"|first=Myles|last=McNutt|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=August 8, 2013|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Mahn deliberated that, growing up poor, a free ride wasn’t a possibility in Vause's world. Vause "left her scruples at the door" when she built her worldly life on an alliance through her father's drug dealer, Mahn assessed. "She worked hard, gambled big, and lost everything". ''[[Autostraddle]]'' posited that Vause hates and fears vulnerability, and the scene where she is locked in a dryer and pleads Chapman to stay echoes the past, when Vause pleaded with Chapman before Chapman left following news of Vause's mother's death. Additionally, Vause is a complicated character for the writer, primarily because she found her sexual threat to Doggett "troubling", while seeing Vause as a young girl "who would do anything for the life she was cheated out of" was something with which she empathized.{{cite web|url=https://www.autostraddle.com/orange-is-the-new-black-episode-111-recap-ya-dun-goofed-190884/|title="Orange Is The New Black" Episode 111 Recap: Ya Dun Goofed|author=Kate|website=[[Autostraddle]]|date=August 13, 2013|accessdate=June 3, 2014}} In ''Den of Geek'', Chris Longo wrote that, as the first season played out, Vause "was vilified, then the tables turned when she won Piper’s friendship, then they turned upside down during their inevitable hookup. Alex, for all the bad she’s done, seems like a woman who stays true to her word. And now after breaking Alex’s (and Larry’s) heart, Piper is the one who’s vilified." Longo praised Prepon's performance, and hoped the series progressed Vause's storylines.{{cite web|url= http://www.denofgeek.com/us/tv/orange-is-the-new-black/170941/orange-is-the-new-black-10-interesting-character-arcs|title=Orange is the New Black: 10 Interesting Character Arcs|first=Chris|last=Longo|website=[[Den of Geek]]|date=August 13, 2013|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} ''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s Tom Meltzer wrote that Prepon plays Chapman's "jilted" former lover "with subtlety and unabashed smoulder".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2013/dec/17/best-tv-2013-orange-is-the-new-black-netflix|title=The best TV of 2013: No 6 – Orange is the New Black (Netflix)|accessdate=April 30, 2017|date=December 17, 2013|author=Meltzer, Tom|website=[[The Guardian]]}} In his review of the first season, Matthew Gilbert of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' described pre-prison Vause as "icy cool", and called Prepon a "revelation" in the role.{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/television/2013/07/10/orange-new-black-yuppie-interrupted/sfQieZah74YFAVWZYugu2O/story.html|title='Orange Is the New Black': Yuppie, interrupted|accessdate=April 30, 2017|date=July 10, 2013|website=[[The Boston Globe]]|author=Gilbert, Matthew}} David Hiltbrand wrote in ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' that Prepon plays the character with "real vigor".{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/columnists/david_hiltbrand/20130711_A_fish_out_of_water_in_the_slammer.html|first=David|title=A fish out of water in the slammer|last=Hiltbrand|website=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=July 11, 2013|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Maureen Ryan of ''[[HuffPost]]'' also praised Prepon's portrayal, commenting that "underneath the cool-girl exterior is a whole lot of pain and loneliness, and Prepon has done a wonderful job of subtly bringing those notes forward."{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/maureen-ryan/orange-is-the-new-black_b_3612375.html|title='Orange Is The New Black': The Year's Best New Show?|first=Maureen|last=Ryan|website=[[HuffPost]]|date=July 17, 2013|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Chris Jancelewicz of ''[[The Huffington Post]] Canada'' deemed Vause "charismatic", adding that Prepon "excels as the bad girl influence".{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/chris-jancelewicz/orange-is-the-new-black-netflix-review_b_3528841.html|title=Orange Is The New Black Review: Time Behind Bars Shouldn't Be This Fun|accessdate=April 30, 2017|date=July 4, 2013|author=Jancelewicz, Chris|website=[[The Huffington Post]]'' Canada''}} Kristi Turnquist of ''[[The Oregonian]]'' stated that although Vause would only be present in a few episodes of the second season, she "turns up to devastating effect early on".{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/index.ssf/2014/05/orange_is_the_new_black_season.html|title='Orange is the New Black' Season 2: A wised-up Piper, more strong women (review)|website=[[The Oregonian]]|first=Kristi|last=Turnquist|date=May 31, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} In a review of the first episode of season two, Horatia Harrod of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' commented that Vause is dedicated to self-preservation and thought that "another betrayal" of Chapman "reached new depths", thus she found it "puzzling" that Vause's bad-girl routine "seems to have won her a fan following, while [Chapman] is reviled."{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/10878040/Orange-is-the-New-Black-episode-one-review-a-sparkling-return-to-form.html|title=Orange is the New Black, episode one, review: 'a sparkling return to form'|last=Harrod|first=Horatia|date=June 6, 2014|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=April 30, 2017}} Kevin Fallon of ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' noted that there is something about Vause that "convinces [Chapman] to throw her lifelong caution to the wind."{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/05/15/orange-is-the-new-black-season-two-is-more-bingeworthy-than-the-first.html|title='Orange Is the New Black' Season Two Is More Bingeworthy Than the First|author=Fallon, Kevin|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=May 15, 2014|accessdate=April 30, 2017}} Kate Zernike of ''[[The New York Times]]'' said that Vause is "calculating" and that "there’s something black cat-like about [her] – she slips into the frame and you know things are about to go bad, or at least, get interesting."{{cite web|url=https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/06/06/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-2-begins-in-a-more-menacing-world/|title='Orange Is the New Black' Recap: Season 2 Begins in a More Menacing World|website=[[New York Times]]|first=Kate|last=Zernike|date=June 6, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Chris Harvey of ''The Daily Telegraph'' described Prepon's turn as "unforgettable" and explained that Vause's wicked attitude and bespectacled look have made the character a "cult favourite".{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/on-demand/2016/06/06/orange-is-the-new-black-author-piper-kerman-people-are-sexual-be/|title=Orange is the New Black author Piper Kerman: 'People are sexual beings, even if you lock them in a cage'|website=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author=Harvey, Chris|date=June 5, 2014|accessdate=April 30, 2017}} In her review of the season two premiere, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''{{'}}s Candace Jackson wrote that "much like in Piper Kerman’s real-life experience, [the Chicago facility] is where [Chapman] runs into Vause". Prepon is "excellent in this role as ever", Jackson commended, walking a "believable line between flirtation and manipulation".{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2014/06/10/orange-is-the-new-black-season-2-episode-1-thirsty-bird-tv-recap/|title='Orange Is the New Black,' Season 2, Episode 1, 'Thirsty Bird': TV Recap|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|first=Candace|last=Jackson|date=June 10, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017|subscription=yes}} Spencer Kornhaber of ''[[The Atlantic]]'' observed that Vause was "correct earlier in [the second season's premiere] when she diagnosed how inconsistent Chapman's worldview is: "it is so hard to keep up with what is black and white for you"." According to Kornhaber, Vause’s "return, in letter and in flashback, offers another lesson in moral relativity and personal transformation. We finally see how [Chapman's] cultivated naivety and [Vause's] cultivated knowingness created a passionate, dangerous pairing early on."{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2014/06/the-orange-is-the-new-black-binge-review-episodes-1-through-6/372320/|title=The Orange Is the New Black Binge Review (Episodes 1 Through 13)|website=[[The Atlantic]]|first=Spencer|last=Kornhaber|date=June 6, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Danielle Henderson remarked in ''[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]'' that Vause "has balls" for sending Chapman letters after the incident in the season two premiere.{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/06/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-2-episode-6-valentines-day.html|title=Orange Is the New Black Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: Are You the Sun?|website=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]|first=Danielle|last=Henderson|date=June 11, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} In her review of the second season's finale, Zernike wrote that although Vause may not be the "typical re-entering felon", her speech to Chapman about needing to violate her probation, flee, and possibly go back to her former felonious life, "does raise some good points" regarding issues with the prison system.{{cite web|url=https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/18/orange-is-the-new-black-finale-its-almost-like-thelma-and-louise/|title='Orange Is the New Black' Finale: It's Almost Like 'Thelma and Louise'|website=[[New York Times]]|first=Kate|last=Zernike|date=July 18, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]''{{'}}s Nico Lang described Vause as a notably popular [[femme fatale]] character, whom the show brought back after the second season "despite the fact that the real-life character was barely in [Kerman's memoir] at all".{{cite news|url=http://www.advocate.com/commentary/2014/06/30/op-ed-orange-new-black-proves-be-model-queer-tv|title=Op-ed: Orange Is the New Black Proves to Be the Model of Queer TV|first=Nico|last=Lang|date=June 30, 2014|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} Charlotte Richardson Andrews wrote in ''[[Sight & Sound]]'' that Vause is one of the show's "believable and investment-worthy" [[queer]] characters, adding that the "tangled, romantic dance that [Vause and Chapman] do is compelling, nuanced and sexy where, in other hands, it might have felt exploitative".{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/sight-sound-magazine/reviews-recommendations/tv/orange-new-black|title=Inside out: Orange Is the New Black|website=[[Sight & Sound]]|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|first=Charlotte|last=Richardson Andrews|date=August 25, 2015}} In ''[[Digital Spy]]'', Emma Dibdin described a "power shift" in the third season between Vause and Chapman and how this positively impacts both characters; "the power dynamic of [Chapman] and [Vause's] relationship is so dramatically shifted that everything about them feels fresh. [Vause] is more vulnerable than we've ever seen her, utterly shattered to find herself back in jail." ''[[The Observer]]''{{'}}s Orly Greenberg said Vause returns to Litchfield "completely absent of her flashing eyes and snarky confidence, instead relying on [Chapman] as an almost maternal figure" as Chapman leads Vause to believe her return to prison is a product of "the system", rather than Chapman's own doing.{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2015/06/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-premiere-review-send-in-the-clowns/|title='Orange is the New Black' Season 3 Premiere Review: Send in the Clowns|first=Orly|last=Greenberg|website=[[The Observer]]|date=June 12, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Emily Ambash of ''CutPrintFilm'' wrote that Vause is "emotionally broken" when she reenters prison; "embarrassed and ashamed of her own choices" and her failure in handling her brief freedom. Vause and Chapman's dynamic in the third season feels "fresh", different from the first season, as they confront their issues in the present without passive aggressiveness and without a focus on the past, Ambash noted; "the characters [are forced to] question their faith not just in each other but also in themselves when dealing with each other."{{cite web|url=http://www.cutprintfilm.com/features/lists-2/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3/|title=Flies in the Web: A Look at 'Orange Is the New Black' Season 3|website=CutPrintFilm|first=Emily|last=Ambash|date=June 1, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Michael Hindle of [[Comingsoon.net]] observed of Vause and Chapman's relationship, while "one has always had power over the other in some form or another now [Vause and Chapman] are more or less on an even playing field".{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/609762-orange-new-black-recap-review-season-3-episodes-2-3|title="Orange is the New Black" Recap & Review: Season 3, Episodes 2 and 3|website=[[Comingsoon.net]]|publisher=[[CraveOnline]]|first=Michael|last=Hindle|date=June 19, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Joshua Alston of ''The A.V. Club'' said that Vause's return to prison "lands with a surprisingly soft impact". The character Stella "appears right on time to drive a wedge between [Chapman] and [Vause] just as a functional relationship becomes possible", and the show "manages to make [the looming love triangle] feel consequential."{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/orange-new-black-still-hot-its-third-season-burns--220759|title=Orange Is The New Black is still hot in its third season, but burns slower than ever|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|first=Joshua|last=Alston|date=June 11, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} In her review of the third season, Jessica Kiang of ''[[Indiewire]]'' wrote that Vause and Chapman "come spectacularly together but find, again with some insight, that they’re a couple whose fire can burn on hate much easier than on routine."{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2015/06/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-review-hate-sex-relapses-mommy-issues-262931/|title='Orange Is The New Black' Season 3 Review: Hate Sex, Relapses & Mommy Issues|website=[[Indiewire]]|first=Jessica|last=Kiang|date=June 16, 2015|accessdate=July 12, 2017}} Libby Hill argued in her ''The New York Times'' review of the season's second episode, that the Vause and Chapman relationship has become "toxic". The on-off lovers have "little meaningful interaction" with other characters while they are entangled in their tempestuous relationship, making them "emotionally unavailable" to other characters and to the audience. Hill hopes Vause is more integrated into "Litchfield's culture" and has more humanizing interactions with other characters as she did with Nichols in the first season.{{cite web|url=https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/06/12/orange-is-the-new-black-bedbugs-season-3-episode-2-recap/|title='Orange Is the New Black' Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: Bedbugs|website=[[New York Times]]|first=Libby|last=Hill|date=June 12, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} In reviewing the season's second episode, ''The A.V. Club''{{'}}s Myles McNutt said that although he understands the attraction of Chapman and Vause and the significance of their intertwined story playing out in prison, their present storyline compels them to exist "independently of anything around them", removing them from ordinary life in the prison community of Litchfield.{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/orange-new-black-bed-bugs-and-beyond-220799|title=Orange Is The New Black: "Bed Bugs and Beyond"|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|first=Myles|last=McNutt|date=June 12, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Perri Nemiroff of ''[[Collider (website)|Collider]]'' felt that it was "an unexpected and unearned twist" that Vause would reconnect with Chapman (through "hate sex") soon after finding out Chapman was responsible for her being back in prison. Their role play in the prison's drama class, however, "balances the palpable hostility with humor and heart, making the scene wildly entertaining, but also ensuring that the moment really means something, too."{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-2-episode-3-recap/|title=Orange Is The New Black Recap: "Bed Bugs And Beyond" & "Empathy Is A Boner Killer"|website=[[Collider]]|first=Perri|last=Nemiroff|date=June 18, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} In ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', Jonathan Dornbush wrote that Vause and Chapman engaging in angry sex after the latter's hand in taking away her freedom is "another shift in their power dynamic". According to Dornbush, this occurs because Vause is "taking control after Piper took it away from her"; "She’s still in jail, she’s still lost her life on the outside, and she may be in more danger now than ever", Dornbush explained, "but at least she can control something."{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/recap/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-2/2/|title=Orange of the New Black recap: Bed Bugs and Beyond|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|first=Jonathan|last=Dornbush|date=June 12, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Ambash said that the drama class [[Improvisational theatre|improv]] exercise is necessary as it compels Vause and Chapman "to consider their real-life situation" and "find a sort of reconciliation".{{cite web|url=http://www.cutprintfilm.com/tv/orange-is-the-new-black-review-3-03-empathy-is-a-boner-killer-3-04-finger-in-the-dyke/|title='Orange Is the New Black' Review: 3.03 "Empathy Is a Boner Killer" / 3.04 "Finger in the Dyke"|website=CutPrintFilm|first=Emily|last=Ambash|date=June 19, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Keith Nelson Jr. of ''[[Digital Trends]]'' found Vause's speech to correctional officer Rogers, on the malleable and interpretive nature of morality, to be frank "societal commentary".{{cite web|url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/movies/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-review/|title=More Laughs, Less Villainy: Orange Is The New Black Season 3 Review|website=[[Digital Trends]]|first=Keith|last=Nelson Jr.|date=June 24, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Sarah Bredeman of ''[[FanSided]]'' opined that the commentary Vause made to Rogers is "one of the best 'we are not your salvation, you can’t save us, and this ain’t no Dead Poet’s Society kinda situation' speeches", and "it really hits home a good point."{{cite web|url=http://hiddenremote.com/2015/06/25/oitnb-recap-ep-3-empathy-boner-killer/|title='OITNB' Recap: Ep 3 'Empathy Is A Boner Killer'|website=Hidden Remote|publisher=[[FanSided]]|first=Sarah|last=Bredeman|date=June 25, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Kelly Lawler in ''[[USA Today]]'' suggested that, as opposed to how Chapman painted her, Vause's legitimate concerns over the danger she is in makes her one of the most rational individuals on the show.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2015/06/13/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-8-recap-fear-and-other-smells/77511464/|title='Orange is the New Black' binge recap: 'Fear, and Other Smells'|website=[[USA Today]]|first=Kelly|last=Lawler|date=June 13, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Perri Nemiroff of ''Collider'' said that Vause's season three flashbacks on her witnessing what her drug cartel boss is capable of made her present situation "far more dynamic and tense", giving her anxiety full credibility.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-8-9-recap/|title=ORANGE IS THE NEW BLACK Recap: "Fear, and Other Smells" & "Where My Dreidel At"|website=[[Collider]]|first=Perri|last=Nemiroff|date=June 29, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Alan Sepinwall of ''[[Uproxx]]'' felt that Vause's flashback, like Nichols' in an earlier episode, was "covering familiar territory solely to support prominent stories each was getting in the present", but at least both flashbacks were "somber" enough to make them an "interesting contrast" to the concurrent comedic moments at Litchfield.{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/sepinwall/review-orange-is-the-new-black-tongue-tiedfear-and-other-smells/|title=Review: 'Orange Is the New Black' – 'Tongue-Tied/Fear, and Other Smells'|website=[[Uproxx]]|first=Alan|last= Sepinwall|date=July 3, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} In his review of the eleventh episode of the season, McNutt wrote that Vause's "isolation is turned around, and what once felt like a failure of the show’s writing becomes a logical character choice." Vause wants no part in what Chapman's prison business has turned into, knowing first-hand the dangers and the damage such an operation can cause. "I find myself respecting [Vause's] struggle to embrace her situation—it may not have served the season to this point," McNutt observed, "but it serves here as a productive counterpoint to [Chapman]".{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/orange-new-black-we-can-be-heroes-221150|title=Orange Is The New Black: "We Can Be Heroes"|first=Myles|last=McNutt|date=June 21, 2015|accessdate=June 6, 2015}} According to Ambash, Vause [and Chapman's] notable absence from the third season's final group scenes – as Vause is trapped with the man who has been sent to kill her, and Chapman is off tattooing herself in the chapel – symbolizes their heightened distrust in others and the prison system itself. "For [Vause], unlike [Chapman], this wasn’t her choice. With safety stripped from her, and ties of trust cut by others, it’s no surprise [Vause] is kept away now from the freedom of the lake."{{cite web|url=http://www.cutprintfilm.com/tv/orange-is-the-new-black-reviews/|title='Orange Is the New Black' Review: 3.11 "We Can Be Heroes" / 3.12 "Don't Make Me Come Back There" / 3.13 "Trust No Bitch"|website=CutPrintFilm|first=Emily|last=Ambash|date=July 21, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Ambash noted that Vause's season three storyline "highlights real issues regarding prisoners’ safety, especially when no real background checks are performed on new, untrained officers, who end up with easy access to inmates". Moreover, "it serves as a reminder that [Vause and Chapman] have basically switched roles" as Chapman embarked on "the smuggling business [and] showed little regard for [Vause]", finding a new sense of power and thrill in her illicit enterprise, while Vause wisely avoided it.{{cite web|url=http://www.cutprintfilm.com/tv/orange-is-the-new-black-review-3-07-tongue-tied-3-08-fear-and-other-smells/|title='Orange Is the New Black' Review: 3.07 "Tongue Tied" / 3.08 "Fear and Other Smells"|website=CutPrintFilm|first=Emily|last=Ambash|date=July 3, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Lauren Chval of ''Chicago Tribune'' remarked that what is great about Vause is "she knows who she is and what she wants", trusts her instincts and has "never flipped on her feelings for Chapman".{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/redeye/redeye-orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-9-recap-20150614-column.html|title='OITNB' episode 9 recap: The hot Aussie just made everything a lot more confusing|website=[[Chicago Tribune]]|first=Lauren|last=Chval|date=June 11, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Chval praised Prepon in the role, and remarked that Vause is "always more interesting in her scenes without Chapman".{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/redeye/redeye-orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-13-recap-20150618-column.html|title='OITNB' episode 13 recap: Let's just be free for a second|website=[[Chicago Tribune]]|first=Lauren|last=Chval|date=June 11, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Perri Nemiroff of ''Collider'' said Prepon has been successful "taking Alex from a strong inmate you don’t want to mess with to someone super vulnerable who’s fearing for her life."{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-12-13-recap/|title=ORANGE IS THE NEW BLACK Recap: "Don't Make Me Come Back There" & "Trust No Bitch"|website=[[Collider]]|first=Perri|last=Nemiroff|date=July 6, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2017}} Rick Porter of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' praised Prepon's performance as Vause, in the season finale, encounters the hitman sent to kill her, writing, "Prepon sells the heck of out Alex's disbelief and fear in the scene." The aftermath of Vause's storyline has a sweeping effect throughout the fourth season according to critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/netflixs-orange-new-black-peaks-its-brilliant-brut-238163|title=Netflix's Orange Is The New Black peaks in its brilliant, brutal fourth season|first=Joshua|last=Alston|date=June 16, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017|website=[[The A.V. Club]]}}{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/tv/orange-is-the-new-black-season-four/2/|title=The Stories Are Darker And The Stakes Are Higher In 'Orange Is The New Black' Season Four|first=Jessica|last=Toomer|date=June 16, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017|website=[[Uproxx]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/06/18/orange-is-the-new-black-season-4-review|title=Orange Is The New Black: Season 4 Review|website=[[IGN]]|first=Matt|last=Fowler|date=June 18, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/oitnbs-search-answers-goes-too-far-exact-wrong-per-238586|title=OITNB's search for answers goes too far for the exact wrong person|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|first=Myles|last=McNutt|date=June 27, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} In ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'', Emma Dibdin wrote that Vause having to kill, dismember, and bury her would-be murderer was "the beginning of a season that saw almost every one of our beloved inmates go through her darkest hour yet."{{cite web|url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/film-tv/a17839/best-tv-shows-2016/|title=The 18 Best Tv Shows Of 2016|first=Emma|last=Dibdin|website=[[Harper's Bazaar]]|date=December 14, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} According to Kayla Kumari Upadhyaya of ''Autostraddle'', Vause and Lolly's "greenhouse murder" became one of the "most suspenseful through lines" of the season. Isabel Mohan wrote in ''The Daily Telegraph'' that Vause's confidence from previous seasons is gone as she has become "a nervous wreck" and "her scenes are among the most macabre" of the season.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/on-demand/2016/06/08/orange-is-the-new-black-season-4-review-could-this-be-the-darkes/|title=Orange is the New Black, season 4, spoiler-free review: is this the darkest season yet?|website=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author=Mohan, Isabel|date=June 16, 2016|accessdate=June 7, 2017}} ''The Atlantic''{{'}}s Spencer Kornhaber considered Vause's "saga" to be some of series' "darkest scenes yet."{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-season-four-episode-one/487235/|website=[[The Atlantic]]|title=Orange Is the New Black: 'Work That Body for Me'|first=Spencer|last=Kornhaber|date=June 17, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Several themes explored in the season are evoked in Vause's storyline. Jen Chaney of ''Vulture'' noted that the "murky issues surrounding blame" are prompted from the outset of the season, as both Vause and Lolly become responsible for the homicide of the hit man, "yet neither of them are true 'murderers' in that both were motivated by self-defense. It’s a case of both women doing wrong and neither of them doing wrong."{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-sympathy-aggressors-season-four.html|website=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]|title=Orange Is the New Black Challenges Us to Sympathize With Aggressors in Season 4|first=Jen|last=Chaney|date=June 20, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Kornhaber of ''The Atlantic'' said that Vause's acknowledgement that her attacker "was a person", echoed "a mantra that’s surfaced in various forms across the season".{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-season-4-episode-13/487586/|website=[[The Atlantic]]|title=Orange Is the New Black: 'Toast Can't Never Be Bread'|first=Spencer|last=Kornhaber|date=June 21, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Myles McNutt of ''The A.V. Club'' wrote, "the season has been consumed by the idea of guilt" and it manifests on Vause and Chapman's attitudes and behavior; in a latter episode, they decide "they aren’t willing to do anything that would add to their sense of guilt".{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/when-guards-freestyle-oitnbs-inmates-become-less-f-238584|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|title=When guards "freestyle," OITNB's inmates become less free|first=Myles|last=McNutt|date=June 25, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} ''Vulture''{{'}}s Kathryn VanArendonk observed the notion that "regret is real, but time only moves in one direction" reflected on Vause and Chapman's conversation about changing the past, and the need to claim selfhood in Vause wanting to acknowledge the humanity of her attacker.{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-4-episode-13.html|website=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]|title=Orange Is the New Black Season Finale Recap: She Was a Person|first=Kathryn|last=VanArendonk|date=June 22, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Myles McNutt wrote that Vause being compelled to finish killing the man, instead of letting him die by Lolly's deed, "makes it more visceral, and creates an internalized event to frame her understanding of her status as a 'criminal' in the season to follow."{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/new-season-oitnb-begins-delusions-gangsta-238249|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|title=A new season of OITNB begins with "delusions of gangsta"|first=Myles|last=McNutt|date=June 17, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Hannah Shaw-Williams of ''[[Screen Rant]]'' regarded Vause taking the life of her attacker as "one of the premiere’s most emotionally powerful scenes, which reveals that despite her background as a hard-as-nails heroin dealer, Vause has never actually had to kill anyone before."{{cite web|url=http://screenrant.com/orange-new-black-season-4-premiere-review/|title=Orange is the New Black Season 4 Premiere Review|website=[[Screen Rant]]|first=Hannah|last=Shaw-Williams|date=June 18, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} In ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste magazine]]'', Matt Brennan commended "the quiet, tearful moment in which [Vause] ... decides to end his life." "Her remorse", Brennan noted, "for this choice, and for all the choices that led to it, is palpable, even if his death amounts to self-defense."{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-review-work-that-body-for.html|title=In the Orange Is the New Black Opener, Piper is Still Dull and the System is Still Broken|website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste magazine]]|first=Matt|last=Brennan|date=June 17, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Emma Dibdin wrote in ''Digital Spy'' that while Vause's on-off lover Chapman "[insists] she's a force to be reckoned with", Vause "goes through the real moral transformation, pushed to brutal extremes by the hitman sent to kill her."{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/orange-is-the-new-black/review/a797787/orange-is-the-new-black-season-4-review/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|title=Orange is the New Black season 4 review: The darkest season yet|first=Emma|last=Dibdin|date=June 14, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Kayla Kumari Upadhyaya of ''Autostraddle'' considered the scenes of Vause helping Lolly reconcile her thoughts and emotions "a cutting and intimate look at self-care and coping mechanisms." ''The Atlantic''{{'}}s Spencer Kornhaber similarly reviewed Vause's "counseling" of Lolly, finding it a "succinct and touching glimpse at post-traumatic coping".{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-episode-three/487427/|website=[[The Atlantic]]|title=Orange Is the New Black: '(Don't) Say Anything'|first=Spencer|last=Kornhaber|date=June 17, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} McNutt opined in ''The A.V. Club'' that the circumstances of Lolly's paranoia, the lack of evidence that the correctional officer was a hit man, the lack of trust in a broken system, and the difficulty in explaining away Vause and Lolly's actions in the homicide, meant that Lolly being taken away was "tragic" but ultimately "probably the best case scenario" when someone would have to be held responsible. ''Autostraddle''{{'s}} Kayla Kumari Upadhyaya considered Vause's decision to not tell Chapman what she has gone through an "emotionally significant" moment for the character. Vause is not on good terms with Chapman, but she also does not want Chapman to be implicated by it, Upadhyaya observed. According to Upadhyaya, apart from it being an overarching plot, the homicide has also had "long-term emotional significance" for Vause.{{cite web|url=https://www.autostraddle.com/orange-is-the-new-black-403-review-dont-say-anything-342338/|website=[[Autostraddle]]|title="Orange Is The New Black" 403 Review: "(Don't) Say Anything"|first=Kayla|last=Kumari Upadhyaya|date=June 19, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Ed Power of ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' found it "wrenching" to see Vause "haunted by doubt and guilt", praising the show for "peeling back the layers, showing a new side to a person we thought we already knew" and the "disquiet and disbelief that flashed across [Vause's] face" in response to Chapman in the [[Crack cocaine|crack]] scene.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/on-demand/2016/06/18/orange-is-the-new-black-season-4-episode-8-recap-hard-to-watch/|website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|title=Orange is the New Black, season 4 episode 8 recap: 'Hard to watch'|first=Ed|last=Power|date=June 18, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Alan Sepinwall of ''Uproxx'' wrote that Vause and Chapman needing to be under the influence of drugs "to finally be honest with each other about all their recent tragedies seemed about right for a relationship that's always thrived on a high level of drama."{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/sepinwall/orange-is-the-new-black-reviewing-every-season-4-episode/|website=[[Uproxx]]|title='Orange Is the New Black': Reviewing every season 4 episode|first=Alan|last=Sepinwall|date=June 19, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} In her review of the season's ninth episode, Pilot Viruet of ''[[Decider (website)|Decider]]'' remarked that it is "good to see [Vause and Chapman] getting along and not plagued by relationship dramatics."{{cite web|url=http://decider.com/2016/07/01/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-4-episode-9-turn-table-turn/|website=[[Decider (website)|Decider]]|title='Orange is the New Black' Recap, Season 4 Episode 9: Civil Disobedience|first=Pilot|last=Viruet|date=July 1, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} In his review of the season's finale, McNutt wrote that he found Vause "reacting to death by thinking about the hitman’s humanity rang true to her arc".{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/oitnbs-finale-system-wants-ignore-what-inmates-can-238840|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|title=In OITNB's finale, the system wants to ignore what the inmates can never forget|first=Myles|last=McNutt|date=June 29, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Prepon received praise for her performance in the fourth season.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-season-4-review-taylor-schilling-taryn-manning-jenji-kohan-netflix-video-1201773432/|title='Orange Is The New Black' Season 4 Review: "S*it" Gets Real & Raw In Strong-As-Ever Netflix Prison Series|first=Dominic|last=Patten|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=June 18, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/tv-blog/index.ssf/2016/06/orange_is_the_new_black_shows_power_of_the_fourth.html#incart_river_index|title='Orange Is the New Black' shows power of the fourth -- season, that is (review)|first=Mark|last=Dawidziak|website=[[The Plain Dealer]]|publisher=[[Advance Digital]]|date=June 11, 2016|accessdate=July 12, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2016/06/orange-is-new-black-season-4-review|title=Simmering Tensions Boil Over in Orange Is the New Black's Outstanding Fourth Season|website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|author=Lawson, Richard|date=June 15, 2016|accessdate=July 12, 2017}} Dana Schwartzof of ''The Observer'' lauded Prepon in the premiere episode writing that her performance should be up for [[Emmy Award|Emmy]] consideration.{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2016/06/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-episode-1/|website=[[The Observer]]|title='Orange is the New Black' Recap: Episode 1|first=Dana|last=Schwartz|date=June 19, 2016|accessdate=July 11, 2017}} Kayla Kumari Upadhyaya of ''Autostraddle'' wrote that Prepon is "giving her best performance to date on the show, effectively capturing the turmoil of Alex’s mind and the psychological toll of this secret." Prepon won the [[Satellite Award for Best Supporting Actress – Series, Miniseries or Television Film]] at the [[18th Satellite Awards]] for her performance as Vause.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/satellite-awards-12-years-a-682716|title=Satellite Awards: '12 Years a Slave' Wins Best Motion Picture|last=Kilday|first=Gregg|date=February 23, 2014|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=August 23, 2015}} ==See also== *[[List of Orange Is the New Black characters|List of ''Orange Is the New Black'' characters]] ==References== {{reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20170224021912/http://www.imdb.com/character/ch0390954/ Alex Vause] on [[IMDb]] {{Orange Is the New Black}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vause, Alex}} [[Category:Female characters in television]] [[Category:Fictional characters based on real people]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2013]] [[Category:Fictional career criminals]] [[Category:Fictional criminals]] [[Category:Fictional drug dealers]] [[Category:Fictional inmates in American federal prisons]] [[Category:Fictional lesbians]] [[Category:Fictional LGBT characters in television]] [[Category:Fictional murderers]] [[Category:Orange Is the New Black characters]]

revision.comment: Linked "chagudax" in text to Wikipedia article "Unangan hunting headgear"
revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Andrew Gronholdt | image = Andrew_gronholdt.jpg | imagesize = 250px | alt = | caption = Andrew Gronholdt holding a chxuusi-x | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1915|08|26}} | birth_place = [[Sand Point, Alaska]], [[Popof Island]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|1998|03|13|1915|08|26}} | death_place = Edmonds, Washington | tribal affiliation = [[Aleut Corporation]] | field = [[woodworking]], [[chagudax]]-carving | training = [[Self-taught]] | movement = Reviving Aleut Bentwood Hat Carving | works = "Chagudax: A Small Window into the Life of an Aleut Bentwood Hat Carver" 2012 | patrons = Aleut Corporation, Shumagin Corporation, Anchorage International Airport, Anchorage Museum | influenced by = Ancient Unangax and Danish Wood Workers | influenced = Okalena Patricia Lekanoff-Gregory, Peter Lind | awards = Shareholder of the Year, Aleut Corporation, 1989 | elected = Board of Directors, Shumagin Corporation, 1972-1974
Board of Directors of the Aleut Corporation, 1977-1998 | website = http://www.andrewgronholdt.com/ }}'''Andrew Gronholdt''' (26 August 1915 – 13 March 1998) was a famous [[Aleut people|Aleut]] from [[Sand Point, Alaska]] in the [[Shumagin Islands]] south of the lower [[Alaska Peninsula]] and became famous for rejuvenating the ancient [[Unangan]] art of carving hunting hats called ''[[Unangan hunting headgear|chagudax]]''. In January 2012, a book was published posthumously by Gronholdt titled "'''''Chagudax''''': A Small Window into the Life of An Aleut Bentwood Hat Carver"*Gronholdt, Andrew. 2012. "Chagudax: A Small Window into the Life of an Aleut Bentwood Hat Carver". San Francisco: Blurb, Inc. Gronholdt's woodworking techniques, wood steaming and bending methods, and instructional design methodologies were legendary. == Early life == Andrew Gronholdt was born on August 26, 1915 in Sand Point on [[Popof Island]] in the [[Shumagin Islands]]. Gronholdt's father was [https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/66249492 Niels Peter Gronholdt] from [[Kerteminde, Denmark]]. Gronholdt's mother is [https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/66298488 Anna Dushkin], who was from a tiny Aleut village on the southside of the Alaska Peninsula named [[Belkofski]], about a dozen miles north east of [[King Cove, Alaska]]. The ancient [[Unangan]] people lived at Belkofski for thousands of years, but the community was closed about 1980 when everyone moved out, mostly to King Cove. Andrew began attending elementary school in Belkofski and later completed grade school in Sand Point in the Shumagin Islands. Graduation from eighth grade at Sand Point School ended Gronholdt's formal education, but "his own desire to discover and explore schooled him for the rest of his life".Dye, Sharon. 2010. Personal conversations with Andrew Gronhold's daughter On January 21, 1942 at [[Unga, Alaska|Unga]], Gronholdt married [https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/66295942 Elisabeth Z. Rodgers], the daughter of Frank Rodgers and Zenia Lois Larsen. They had one child, born in Seward. ==Chagudax== [[File:Andrew gronholdt photography by david l clark slight retouch.jpg|thumb|right|alt text|Gronholdt Photo by David L. Clark, 1966]] While living in Sand Point on Popof Island in the [[Shumagin Islands]] amongst the members of the [http://qttribe.org/ Qagun Tayagungin Tribe], the [https://web.archive.org/web/20110419203706/http://www.ungatribe.org/ Unga Tribe], and the Pauloff Harbor Tribe, Gronholdt designed ''chagudax'' (the ancient [[Unangan]] word for "hunting visor") in the [[Aleutians]]. Based upon the elaborate design of his maritime hunting ancestors, Gronholdt carved slabs of wood into thin blanks which he steamed and bent over molds to form the complex shapes of these ancient bentwood hats. He began researching hat construction methods in 1985. Gronholdt, believing that the creation of these bentwood hunting hats was an important component of the ancient Unangan culture, went from [[Sand Point, Alaska|Sand Point]] to several other communities within the Aleutians, teaching others this lost art.Black, Lydia T. "Aleut Art: Unangam Aguqaadangin". Anchorage, Alaska: Aleutian/Pribilof Islands Association, 2003 Gronholdt taught at several schools including Sand Point and Unalaska. Gronholdt's students teach chagudax at Aleut cultural camps.{{YouTube|tLnPHWTi-Fs|Aleut culture camps}} The chagudax classes are well attended, often filled to the limit. Students cherish the chagudax which they carved, steamed, and bent. They carry them home with a deep sense of cultural pride as a symbol of ancient Aleut ways. The ''chagudax'' was an important component of the [[Unangan]] sea kayaker's hunting and battle uniform.Black, Lydia T. "Glory Remembered: Wooden Headgear of Alaska Sea Hunters." Juneau, Alaska: Alaska State Museums, 1991. The sight of a fleet of Aleut men, fully dressed in battle uniform with their ''chagudax'' and the decks of their sea kayaks bristling with razor sharp spears with which they were deadly accurate at long distances, struck fear into the hearts of enemies and excitement into the hearts of Aleut women. "All travelers are unanimous in stating that the Aleut in full attire and in his baidarka has a handsome and indeed a majestic appearance"(p. 275)Veniaminov, Ivan. "Notes on the Islands of the Unalashka District". Kingston, Ontario: The Limestone Press, 1984. Gronholdt's visors are featured in collections at the [[Anchorage International Airport]], the [[Unalaska]] City School Percent for Art, the Shumagin Corporation and the Aleutian/Pribilof Islands Association. ==Gronholdt's other skills== Gronholdt had a background as a wooden boat builder. He also crafted wooden pumps, known as '''chxuusi-x''',Bergsland, Knut. "Aleut Dictionary: Unangam Tunudgusii". Fairbanks, Alaska: Alaska Native Language Center, 1994 which was used to bail water out of the skin-on-frame [[iqyax]], the Aleut sea kayaks. ==Civic life== Gronholdt believed in the importance of the Aleut people getting involved and voicing their opinion to help make the community better, serving on the Board of Directors for the Shumagin Corporation (1972 through 1974) and serving for over 21 years (1977 through 1998) on the Board of Directors in several positions at the Aleut Corporation.[http://www.aleutcorp.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=19&Itemid=32 "Past TAC Directors."] ''The Aleut Corporation''. 2008 (retrieved 28 March 2011) ==Wood bending traditions== In September 1989, Gronholdt was chosen as an instructor at the Institute of Alaska Native Art's prestigious ''Bending Tradition'' program which was "charged with creative energy" (p. 10) and his area of the wood working shop quickly became known as "Aleut Corner" (p. 10) as the plethora of bentwood hunting visors poured forth. Okalena Patricia Lekanoff-Gregory, Unalaska Aleut artist, has been one of Gronholdt's more prolific students, having instructed classes throughout the Aleutians and Northwest United States. At the beginning of each of her classes, Okalena Patricia Lekanoff-Gregory tells all of her new students about her great instructor, Andrew Gronholdt, and has a fine portrait of Gronholdt displayed at the carving table, next to the carving knives. An important component of Aleut values is to acknowledge Unangax elders. In 2011 Lekanoff-Gregory worked with the Smithsonian's Arctic Studies Center to produce a video titled {{YouTube|bmhSelrkFEk|"The Artistry and History of the Aleutian Islands Bentwood Hat"}} in which she provides an overview of how the bentwood hats are carved, steamed, and bent. Lekanoff-Gregory also honors having learned chagudax from Gronholdt. ==Death and legacy== Gronholdt died on March 13, 1998 in [[Edmonds, Washington]] at the age of 82.{{Cite news |url=http://www.ankn.uaf.edu/sop/sopv3i4.pdf |first=Jerah |last=Chadwick |title=Revival of Unangax̂/Aleut Hatmaking: In Memory of Andrew Gronholdt |work=Sharing Our Pathways |volume=3 |issue=4 |date=September–October 1998 |accessdate=9 February 2010}} Gronholdt was laid to rest at Evergreen Washelli Memorial Park next to his wife [https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/66295942 Elisabeth]. Their gravestone is engraved, "[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=gronholdt&GSfn=andrew&GSbyrel=all&GSdyrel=all&GSob=n&GRid=66148152&df=all& Together Forever]".[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/66148152 "Andrew Gronholdt."] ''Find a Grave''. (retrieved 28 March 2010) Since his death, some of his former students have continued his teaching. His legacy of building ''chagudax'' continues into the future as instructors at Aleut culture camp use forms and jigs he built to teach new generations about the proud warriors who defended their coastal villages wearing these unique hunting visors. The [[Aleut Foundation]] offers the Andrew Gronholdt Scholarship Award to Aleut students majoring in the arts.[http://www.thealeutfoundation.org/ScholarshipGuide.aspx "Scholarship Guide."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724015049/http://www.thealeutfoundation.org/ScholarshipGuide.aspx |date=July 24, 2011 }} ''The Aleut Foundation.'' (retrieved 28 March 2011) ==Publications== In January 2012 Gronholdt's photographs, diary, and drawings were published in a book titled "[http://www.blurb.com/bookstore/detail/2873796 Chagudax: A Small Window into the Life of an Aleut Bentwood Hat Carver]". Most of the material in the book was created by Gronholdt and includes many photographs of the chagudax which he designed, carved, steamed and bent. The 96-page book, edited by Michael Livingston and Sharon Gronholdt-Dye, contains 144 illustrations. Gronholdt's diary details his younger years in the Shumagin Islands when times were sometimes hardscrabble such as near-starvation of the entire Gronholdt family on remote Dolgoi Island in the 1920s. Gronholdt's distinctly optimistic world view shines a bright light into life in the Shumagin Islands in the early 20th century. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== *Bergsland, Knut. "Aleut Dictionary: Unangam Tunudgusii". Fairbanks, Alaska: Alaska Native Language Center. *Black, Lydia T. "Glory Remembered: Wooden Headgear of Alaska Sea Hunters." Juneau, Alaska: Alaska State Museums, 1991. *Black, Lydia T. "Aleut Art: Unangam Aguqaadangin". Anchorage, Alaska: Aleutian/Pribilof Islands Association, 2003. *Dye, Sharon. 2010. Personal conversations with Andrew Gronhold's daughter. *Gronholdt, Andrew. 2012. "Chagudax: A Small Window into the Life of an Aleut Bentwood Hat Carver". San Francisco: Blurb, Inc. *Sharing Our Pathways. A newsletter of the Alaska Rural Systemic Initiative Alaska Federation of Natives / University of Alaska / National Science Foundation. Volume 3, Issue 4, September/October 1998 *Veniaminov, Ivan. "Notes on the Islands of the Unalashka District". Kingston, Ontario: The Limestone Press, 1984. *Wallen, Lynn Ager. "Bending Traditions". Fairbanks, Alaska: Institute of Alaska Native Arts, 1990. {{DEFAULTSORT:Gronholdt, Andrew}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:1998 deaths]] [[Category:Native American woodcarvers]] [[Category:Alaska Native people]] [[Category:American people of Aleut descent]] [[Category:American people of Danish descent]] [[Category:American woodworkers]] [[Category:Artists from Alaska]] [[Category:People from Aleutians East Borough, Alaska]] [[Category:20th-century American sculptors]] [[Category:American male sculptors]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox character | name = Arnold Judas Rimmer BSC, SSC | series = [[Red Dwarf]] | image = [[File:ArnoldRimmer1.jpg|250px]] | caption = | first = "[[The End (Red Dwarf)|The End]]" | last = | nickname = Goal Post Head, Alphabet Head, - Smeg Head, Trans-Am Wheel-arch Nostrils, Bonehead, Captain Bollocks, Ace-hole | alias = Ace Rimmer, Billy Doyle | species = Human / Hologram | gender = Male | occupation = Technician, Second Class (series), Technician, First Class (books) | family = Lecturer Rimmer (stepfather)
John Rimmer (half-brother)
Frank Rimmer (half-brother)
Howard Rimmer (half-brother){{refn|group="note"|Frank is first named as Rimmer's brother in "[[Better Than Life (Red Dwarf)|Better Than Life]]" (1988),{{Cite episode |title=Better Than Life |episode-link=Better Than Life (Red Dwarf) |url= |access-date= |series=Red Dwarf |series-link=Red Dwarf |first=Rob |last=Grant |author-link=Rob Grant |first2=Doug (writers) |last2=Naylor |author-link2=Doug Naylor |first3=Ed (director) |last3=Bye |author-link3=Ed Bye |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC2]] |city= |date=13 September 1988 |season= |series-no=II |number=2 |minutes= |time= |transcript= |transcript-url= |quote= |language=}} while John and Howard are named in "[[Polymorph (Red Dwarf episode)|Polymorph]]" (1989).{{Cite episode |title=Polymorph |episode-link=Polymorph (Red Dwarf episode) |url= |access-date= |series=Red Dwarf |series-link=Red Dwarf |first=Rob |last=Grant |author-link=Rob Grant |first2=Doug (writers) |last2=Naylor |author-link2=Doug Naylor |first3=Ed (director) |last3=Bye |author-link3=Ed Bye |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC2]] |city= |date=28 November 1989 |season= |series-no=III |number=3 |minutes= |time= |transcript= |transcript-url= |quote= |language=}} In "[[The Beginning (Red Dwarf)|The Beginning]]" (2012), the man Rimmer thought was his father (played by [[Simon Treves]]) confirms in a recorded message that he is not in fact Rimmer's father.{{Cite episode |title=The Beginning |episode-link=The Beginning (Red Dwarf) |url= |access-date= |series=Red Dwarf |series-link=Red Dwarf |first=Doug (writer/director) |last=Naylor |author-link=Doug Naylor |network=[[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]] |station= |city= |date=8 November 2012 |season= |series-no=X |number=6 |minutes= |time= |transcript= |transcript-url= |quote= |language=}}}} | spouse = | relatives = Dungo the Gardener (biological father)
Michael McGruder (son; ''[[Last Human]]'' continuity only) | episode = | portrayer = [[Chris Barrie]] | creator = [[Rob Grant]] and [[Doug Naylor]] }} '''Arnold Judas Rimmer''' is a [[fictional character]] in the [[science fiction]] [[situation comedy]] ''[[Red Dwarf]]'', played by [[Chris Barrie]]. He is unpopular with his crewmates, and is often the target of insults and general ridicule. After he is killed by a radiation leak during a [[timeskip]] in the series' first episode "[[The End (Red Dwarf)|The End]]" (1988) Rimmer is present for most of the series as a computer-generated [[Holography|hologram]], indicated by the ‘H’ symbol on his forehead. From series I-V, Rimmer is intangible as a hologram and unable to interact with his environment, referred to in-universe as 'soft-light'; come the series VI episode "[[Legion (Red Dwarf)|Legion]]" (1993), Rimmer is upgraded as a 'hard-light' hologram where he is now able to interact with his surroundings as well as being essentially indestructible, yet still able to feel pain. Following the character's departure in the series VII episode "[[Stoke Me a Clipper]]" (1997), Rimmer is absent from the show until series VIII, where a flesh and blood version of Rimmer is shown having been resurrected by [[nanobot]]s with no memory of the hologrammatic Rimmer's experiences and only those of Rimmer prior to the radiation leak in the first episode. However, following a ten-year hiatus after series VIII, the character reappeared as a hologram in the miniseries ''[[Red Dwarf: Back to Earth|Back to Earth]]'' (2009) onward. It remains unclear whether this incarnation of Rimmer seen in ''Back to Earth'' and later series is the original hologram from series I-VII or a hologram of the Rimmer introduced in series VIII that was resurrected through [[nanotechnology]]. The fictional world of ''Red Dwarf'' would also allow for the possibility of Rimmer's latest incarnation being an amalgamation of the memories of both.{{Cite episode |title=M-Corp |episode-link=M-Corp (Red Dwarf) |url= |access-date= |series=Red Dwarf |series-link=Red Dwarf |first=Doug (writer/director) |last=Naylor |author-link=Doug Naylor |network=[[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]] |station= |date=9 November 2017 |season= |series-no=XII |number=5 |minutes= |time= |transcript= |transcript-url= |quote= |language=}} The [[Grant Naylor|creators]] of the series acknowledge that Rimmer's [[surname]] comes from a snobby [[Prefect#Academic|prefect]] with whom they attended school.
