revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=March 2013}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:SamYbarra.jpg|thumb|200px|Ybarra beneath sandbags]] -->'''Sam Ybarra''' (1945-1982) was a [[United States Army]] soldier who served in the [[Tiger Force]] commando unit attached to the [[101st Airborne Division]] during the [[Vietnam War]]. He is notable for alleged involvement in warcrimes alongside the Tiger Force unit.
Ybarra was born and raised on the [[San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation]] in [[Arizona]] to a [[Mexican people|Mexican]] father and an [[Apache people|Apache]] mother. When he was five, his father died in a bar brawl, and after that he was raised by his mother. He attended [[Globe High School]] in [[Globe, Arizona]], and was arrested four times as a teenager for disturbing the peace and underage drinking.
Ybarra enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1966, along with his childhood friend Kenneth Green, and the friends were attached to the Tiger Force unit. Both he and Green committed atrocities against Vietnamese civilians during the war, and engaged in the Tiger Force practice of cutting off trophy ears from their victims.
Ybarra was noted by the ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]'' magazine as having recorded the 1000th kill of [[Operation Wheeler/Wallowa|Operation Wheeler]].
Green was killed on September 29, 1967, and other Tiger Force soldiers claim that it threw Ybarra over the edge, as he vowed to avenge his friend's death. As a result, he became the unit's worst killer, and had to be transferred out of the unit to an artillery company in early 1968. Ybarra went on to be [[court martial]]ed for insubordination, and was dishonorably discharged in late 1968. He would later be named in 7 of the 30 allegations that the Army would later investigate the unit for.
Once discharged, Ybarra could not be compelled to testify to the investigations against him, and declined three times. He died of pneumonia in 1982, at age 37, living with his mother on the San Carlos Apache Reservation in Arizona, reportedly contrite and depressed over his role in the war.
==See also== {{portal|United States Army}}
==References== {{Reflist}} * Sallah, Michael and Mitch Weiss. ''Tiger Force: A True Story of Men and War''. New York: Little, Brown and Company, 2006, {{ISBN|0316159972}} * Greiner, Bernd. ''Krieg ohne Fronten: Die USA in Vietnam''. Hamburg: Hamburger Edition, 2007. [https://web.archive.org/web/20080518051548/http://www.his-online.de/cms.asp?IDN=232&H='58'&T=0&Plugin=10&HE=10&HEP=978%2D3%2D936096%2D80%2D4], {{ISBN|9783936096804}} * Toledo Blade Article Series on Tiger Force [http://www.toledoblade.com/apps/pbcs.dll/section?Category=SRTIGERFORCE]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ybarra, Sam}} [[Category:Apache people]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:American army personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:American people of Mexican descent]] [[Category:Native American United States military personnel]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:1982 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]]

revision.comment: Added information about current seventy (Latter-day Saint movement) to main body; removed same link from "See Also" section.
revision.text:
[[File:70Apostles.jpg|thumb|[[Icon]] of the Seventy Apostles.{{when|date=October 2015}}]] The '''seventy disciples''' or '''seventy-two disciples''' (known in the [[Eastern Christianity|Eastern Christian]] traditions as the '''Seventy[-two] Apostles''') were early emissaries of [[Jesus]] mentioned in the [[Gospel of Luke]].{{bibleref2|Luke|10:1–24}} According to Luke, the only [[gospel]] in which they appear, Jesus appointed them and sent them out in pairs on a specific mission which is detailed in the text. In [[Western Christianity]], they are usually referred to as [[Disciple (Christianity)|disciples]],[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05029a.htm Catholic Encyclopedia: Disciple]: "The disciples, in this disciples, in this context, are not the crowds of believers who flocked around Christ, but a smaller body of His followers. They are commonly identified with the seventy-two (seventy, according to the received Greek text, although several Greek manuscripts mention seventy-two, as does the Vulgate) referred to ({{bibleref2|Luke|10:1}}) as having been chosen by Jesus. The names of these disciples are given in several lists (Chronicon Paschale, and Pseudo-Dorotheus in Migne, P.G., XCII, 521–524; 543–545; 1061–1065); but these lists are unfortunately worthless." whereas in Eastern Christianity they are usually referred to as [[Apostle (Christian)|Apostles]].{{cite web|url=http://ocafs.oca.org/FeastSaintsLife.asp?FSID=100017|title=Synaxis of the Seventy Apostles|work=oca.org}} Using the original [[Greek language|Greek words]], both titles are descriptive, as an ''apostle'' is one sent on a [[Mission (Christian)|mission]] (the Greek uses the verb form: ''apesteilen'') whereas a ''disciple'' is a student, but the two traditions differ on the scope of the words ''apostle'' and ''disciple''. Although apostles and disciples exist in many extant churches and denominations, the [[Latter Day Saint movement]] is the only current one to use [[Seventy (Latter Day Saints)|Seventy]] as a title for a priesthood office.{{sourcetext|source=The Doctrine and Covenants|book=Section 107|verse=25|showsource=x}} == Text == The passage from [[Luke 10]] reads (in [[Young's Literal Translation]]):{{quote| And after these things, the Lord did appoint also other seventy, and sent them by twos before his face, to every city and place whither he himself was about to come, then said he unto them, `The harvest indeed [is] abundant, but the workmen few; beseech ye then the Lord of the harvest, that He may put forth workmen to His harvest. `Go away; lo, I send you forth as lambs in the midst of wolves; carry no bag, no scrip, nor sandals; and salute no one on the way; and into whatever house ye do enter, first say, Peace to this house; and if indeed there may be there the son of peace, rest on it shall your peace; and if not so, upon you it shall turn back. `And in that house remain, eating and drinking the things they have, for worthy [is] the workman of his hire; go not from house to house, and into whatever city ye enter, and they may receive you, eat the things set before you, and heal the ailing in it, and say to them, The reign of God hath come nigh to you. `And into whatever city ye do enter, and they may not receive you, having gone forth to its broad places, say, And the dust that hath cleaved to us, from your city, we do wipe off against you, but this know ye, that the reign of God hath come nigh to you; and I say to you, that for Sodom in that day it shall be more tolerable than for that city. `Wo to thee, Chorazin; wo to thee, Bethsaida; for if in Tyre and Sidon had been done the mighty works that were done in you, long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes, they had reformed; but for Tyre and Sidon it shall be more tolerable in the judgment than for you. `And thou, Capernaum, which unto the heaven wast exalted, unto hades thou shalt be brought down. `He who is hearing you, doth hear me; and he who is putting you away, doth put me away; and he who is putting me away, doth put away Him who sent me.' And the seventy turned back with joy, saying, `Sir, and the demons are being subjected to us in thy name;' and he said to them, `I was beholding the Adversary, as lightning from the heaven having fallen; lo, I give to you the authority to tread upon serpents and scorpions, and on all the power of the enemy, and nothing by any means shall hurt you; but, in this rejoice not, that the spirits are subjected to you, but rejoice rather that your names were written in the heavens.'{{bibleref2|Luke|10:1–20|YLT}}}} == Analysis == This is the only mention of the group in the [[Bible]]. The number is ''seventy'' in some manuscripts of the [[Alexandrian text-type|Alexandrian]] (such as [[Codex Sinaiticus]]) and [[Caesarean text-type|Caesarean]] text traditions but ''seventy-two'' in most other Alexandrian and [[Western text-type|Western]] texts. It may derive from the [[Sons of Noah|seventy nations of Genesis 10]] or the many other occurrences of the number seventy in the Bible, or the seventy-two translators of the [[Septuagint]] from the [[Letter of Aristeas]].[[Bruce Metzger]]'s ''Textual Commentary on the Greek NT'' In translating the ''[[Vulgate]]'', [[Jerome]] selected the reading of seventy-two. The ''Gospel of Luke'' is not alone among the [[synoptic gospels]] in containing multiple episodes in which Jesus sends out his followers on missions. The first occasion ({{bibleref2|Luke|9:1–6}}) is closely based on the "limited commission" mission in ''[[Gospel of Mark|Mark]]'' {{bibleref2|Mark|6:6–13}}, which however recounts the sending out of the [[twelve apostles]], rather than seventy, though with similar details. The parallels (also [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] {{bibleref2|Matthew|9:35}}, {{bibleref2|Matthew|10:1}}, {{bibleref2|Matthew|10:5–42}}) suggest a common origin in the hypothesized [[Q document]]. Luke also mentions the [[Great Commission]] to "all nations" ({{bibleref2|Luke|24:44–49}}) but in less detail than Matthew's account and {{bibleverse|Mark|16:19–20}} mentions the [[Dispersion of the Apostles]]. What has been said to the seventy (two) in {{bibleref2|Luke|10:4}} is referred in passing to the Twelve in {{bibleref2|Luke|22:35}}: :He said to them, "When I sent you forth without a money bag or a sack or sandals, were you in need of anything?" "No, nothing," they replied. == Feast days == [[File:Erastus, Olympus, Rhodion, Sosipater, Quartus and Tertius (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumbnail|Erastus, Olympus, Rhodion, Sosipater, Quartus and Tertius]] [[File:Stachys, Amplias, Urban (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumbnail|Stachys, Amplias, Urban]] [[File:Patrobulus, Hermas, Linus, Caius, Philologus of 70 disciples (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumbnail|Patrobulus, Hermas, Linus, Caius, Philologus]] [[File:Sosthenes, Apollo, Cephas, Tychicus, Epaphroditus, Cæsar and Onesiphorus of 70 disciples (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumbnail|Sosthenes, Apollo, Cephas, Tychicus, Epaphroditus, Cæsar and Onesiphorus]] The [[feast day]] commemorating the seventy is known as the "[[Synaxis]] of the Seventy Apostles" in Eastern Orthodoxy, and is celebrated on [[January 4 (Eastern Orthodox liturgics)|January 4]]. Each of the seventy apostles also has individual commemorations scattered throughout the [[liturgical year]] (see [[Eastern Orthodox Church calendar]]). == The record by Pseudo-Hippolytus == [[Hippolytus of Rome]] was a disciple of [[Irenaeus]], a disciple of [[Polycarp]], a disciple of [[Apostle John]]. Hippolytus's works were considered lost prior to their discovery at a monastery on [[Mount Athos]] in 1854.Ante-Nicean Fathers, ed. Alexander Roberts, James Donaldson and A. Cleaveland Coxe, vol. 5 (Peabody MA: Hendrickson Publishers, 1999), 3 While his major work ''The Refutation of All Heresies'' was readily accepted (once the false attribution to Origen was resolved), his two small works, ''On the Twelve Apostles of Christ'' and ''On the Seventy Apostles of Christ'', are still regarded as dubious, put in the appendix of his works in the voluminous collection of the writings of early church fathers.Ante-Nicean Fathers, ed. Alexander Roberts, James Donaldson and A. Cleaveland Coxe, vol. 5 (Peabody MA: Hendrickson Publishers, 1999), 254–56 Here is the complete text of Pseudo-Hippolytus's ''On the Seventy Apostles of Christ'':
# [[James the Just|James the Lord's brother]], bishop of Jerusalem. # [[Cleopas]], bishop of Jerusalem. # [[Saint Matthias|Matthias]], who supplied the vacant place in the number of the twelve apostles. # [[Thaddeus of Edessa|Thaddeus]], who conveyed the epistle to Augarus ([[Abgar V]]). # [[Ananias of Damascus|Ananias]], who baptized Paul, and was bishop of Damascus. # [[St Stephen|Stephen]], the first martyr. # [[Philip the Evangelist|Philip]], who baptized the eunuch. # [[Prochorus (deacon)|Prochorus]], bishop of Nicomedia, who also was the first that departed, 11 believing together with his daughters. # [[Nicanor the Deacon|Nicanor]] died when Stephen was martyred. # [[Timon the Deacon|Timon]], bishop of Bostra. # [[Parmenas]], bishop of Soli. # [[Nicolas the Deacon|Nicolaus]], bishop of Samaria. # [[Barnabas]], bishop of Milan. # [[Mark the Evangelist]], bishop of Alexandria. # [[Luke the Evangelist]]. These two belonged to the seventy disciples who were scattered by the offence of the word which Christ spoke, “Except a man eat my flesh, and drink my blood, he is not worthy of me.” But the one being induced to return to the Lord by Peter’s instrumentality, and the other by Paul’s, they were honored to preach that Gospel on account of which they also suffered martyrdom, the one being burned, and the other being crucified on an olive tree.
  1. [[Silas]], bishop of Corinth.
  2. [[Silvanus of the Seventy|Silvanus]], bishop of Thessalonica.
  3. [[Crescens|Crisces (Crescens)]], bishop of Carchedon in Gaul.
  4. [[Epenetus of Carthage|Epænetus]], bishop of Carthage.
  5. [[Andronicus of Pannonia|Andronicus]], bishop of Pannonia.
  6. [[Ampliatus|Amplias]], bishop of Odyssus.
  7. [[Urban of Macedonia|Urban]], bishop of Macedonia.
  8. [[Stachys the Apostle|Stachys]], bishop of Byzantium.
  9. Barnabas, bishop of Heraclea
  10. Phygellus, bishop of Ephesus. He was of the party also of Simon.
  11. Hermogenes. He, too, was of the same mind with the former.
  12. [[Demas]], who also became a priest of idols.
  13. [[Apelles of Heraklion|Apelles]], bishop of Smyrna.
  14. [[Aristobulus of Britannia|Aristobulus]], bishop of Britain.
  15. [[Narcissus of Athens|Narcissus]], bishop of Athens.
  16. Herodion, bishop of Tarsus.
  17. [[Agabus]] the prophet.
  18. [[Rufus of Thebes|Rufus]], bishop of Thebes.
  19. [[Asyncritus of Hyrcania|Asyncritus]], bishop of Hyrcania.
  20. [[Phlegon of Marathon|Phlegon]], bishop of Marathon.
  21. [[Hermas of Dalmatia|Hermes]], bishop of Dalmatia.
  22. Patrobulus, bishop of Puteoli.
  23. Hermas, bishop of Philippi.
  24. [[Pope Linus|Linus]], bishop of Rome.
  25. [[Gaius of Ephesus|Caius]], bishop of Ephesus.
  26. [[Philologus of Sinope|Philologus]], bishop of Sinope
  27. and 43. [[Olympas|Olympus]] and [[Herodion of Patras|Rhodion]] were martyred in Rome.
  1. [[Lucius of Cyrene|Lucius]], bishop of Laodicea in Syria.
  2. [[Jason of Thessalonica|Jason]], bishop of Tarsus.
  3. [[Sosipater]], bishop of Iconium
  4. [[Tertius of Iconium|Tertius]], bishop of Iconium.
  5. [[Erastus of Corinth|Erastus]], bishop of Panellas.
  6. [[Quartus]], bishop of Berytus.
  7. [[Apollos]], bishop of Cæsarea.
  8. [[Cephas of Iconium|Cephas]].
  9. [[Sosthenes]], bishop of Colophonia.
  10. [[Tychicus]], bishop of Colophonia.
  11. [[Epaphroditus]], bishop of Andriace.
  12. [[Caesar of Dyrrhachium|Cæsar]], bishop of Dyrrachium.
  13. [[Mark of Apollonias|Mark]], cousin to Barnabas, bishop of Apollonia.
  14. [[Justus of Eleutheropolis|Justus]], bishop of Eleutheropolis.
  15. [[Artemas of Lystra|Artemas]], bishop of Lystra.
  16. [[Clement of Sardice|Clement]], bishop of Sardinia.
  17. [[Onesiphorus]], bishop of Corone.
  18. [[Tychicus of Chalcedon|Tychicus]], bishop of Chalcedon.
  19. [[Carpus of Beroea|Carpus]], bishop of Berytus in Thrace.
  20. [[Evodius|Evodus]], bishop of Antioch.
  21. [[Aristarchus of Apamea|Aristarchus]], bishop of Apamea.
  22. [[John Mark|Mark, who is also John]], bishop of Bibloupolis.
  23. [[Zenas the Lawyer|Zenas]], bishop of Diospolis.
  24. [[Philemon (New Testament person)|Philemon]], bishop of Gaza.
  25. Aristarchus.
  26. Pudes.
  27. [[Trophimus]], who was martyred along with Paul.
== The first list and other lists == Many of the names included among the seventy are recognizable for their other achievements. The names included in various lists differ slightly. In the lists, [[Luke the Evangelist|Luke]] is also one of these seventy himself. The following list gives a widely accepted [[wikt:canon|canon]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} Their names are listed below: # James "the Lord's brother" ([[James the Just]]), author of the [[Epistle of James]], and first [[Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem#Bishops of Jerusalem|Bishop of Jerusalem]]. {{bibleref2|Matthew|13:55}}; {{bibleref2|Mark|6:3}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|12:17}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|15:13}}; [[Epistle of James]]. # Agabus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|11:28}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|21:10}}. # Amplias. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:8}} # [[Mark the Evangelist]], author of the Gospel of Mark and [[Patriarch of Alexandria|Bishop of Alexandria]] # [[Luke the Evangelist]], author of the Gospel of Luke # [[Cleopas]] # [[Simeon of Jerusalem|Simeon]], son of Cleopas, 2nd Bishop of Jerusalem # [[Barnabas]], companion of Paul # [[Justus of Eleutheropolis|Justus]], Bishop of [[Eleutheropolis]] # [[Thaddeus of Edessa]] (not the [[Jude the Apostle|Apostle called Thaddeus]]), also known as [[Saint Addai]] # [[Ananias of Damascus|Ananias]], Bishop of [[Damascus]] # [[Saint Stephen|Stephen]], one of the [[Seven Deacons]], the first [[martyr]] # [[Philip the Evangelist]], one of the Seven Deacons, Bishop of [[Tralles]] in [[Asia Minor]] # [[Prochorus the Deacon|Prochorus]], one of the Seven Deacons, Bishop of [[Nicomedia]] in [[Bithynia]] # [[Nicanor the Deacon]], one of the Seven Deacons # [[Timon the Deacon|Timon]], one of the Seven Deacons # [[Parmenas the Deacon]], one of the Seven Deacons # [[Saint Timothy|Timothy]], [[Bishop of Ephesus]] # [[Apostle Titus|Titus]], Bishop of [[Crete]] # [[Philemon (New Testament character)|Philemon]], Bishop of [[Gaza City|Gaza]] # Onesimus (Not the [[Onesimus]] mentioned in the [[Epistle to Philemon]]) # [[Epaphras]], Bishop of Andriaca # [[Archippus]] # [[Silas]], Bishop of [[Corinth]] # [[Silvanus of the Seventy|Silvanus]] # [[Crescens]] # [[Crispus of Chalcedon|Crispus]], Bishop of [[Chalcedon]] in [[Galilee]] # [[Epenetus of Carthage|Epenetus]], Bishop of [[Carthage]] # [[Andronicus of Pannonia|Andronicus]], Bishop of [[Pannonia]] # [[Stachys the Apostle|Stachys]], [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople|Bishop of Byzantium]] # [[Ampliatus|Amplias]], Bishop of Odissa ([[Odessus]]) # [[Urban of Macedonia|Urban]], Bishop of [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]] # [[Narcissus of Athens|Narcissus]], [[List of Archbishops of Athens|Bishop of Athens]] # [[Apelles of Heraklion|Apelles]], Bishop of [[Heraklion]] # [[Aristobulus of Britannia|Aristobulus]], Bishop of Britain # [[Herodion of Patras|Herodion]], Bishop of [[Patras]] # [[Agabus]] the [[Prophet]] # [[Rufus of Thebes|Rufus]], Bishop of [[Thebes (Greece)|Thebes]] # [[Asyncritus of Hyrcania|Asyncritus]], Bishop of [[Hyrcania]] # [[Phlegon of Marathon|Phlegon]], Bishop of [[Marathon, Greece|Marathon]] # [[Hermes of Philippopolis|Hermes]], Bishop of [[Plovdiv|Philippopolis]] # [[Parrobus of Pottole|Parrobus]], Bishop of [[Pottole]] # [[Hermas of Dalmatia|Hermas]], Bishop of [[Dalmatia]] # [[Pope Linus]], [[Bishop of Rome]] # [[Gaius of Ephesus|Gaius]], Bishop of Ephesus # [[Philologus of Sinope|Philologus]], Bishop of [[Sinop, Turkey|Sinope]] # [[Lucius of Cyrene]], Bishop of [[Latakia|Laodicea]] in [[Syria]] # [[Jason of Thessalonica|Jason]], Bishop of [[Tarsus (city)|Tarsus]] # [[Sosipater of Iconium|Sosipater]], Bishop of [[Iconium]] # [[Olympas]] # [[Tertius of Iconium|Tertius]], transcriber of the [[Epistle to the Romans]] and Bishop of Iconium # [[Erastus of Paneas|Erastus]], Bishop of [[Paneas]] # [[Quartus of Berytus|Quartus]], Bishop of [[Beirut|Berytus]] # [[Euodias of Antioch|Euodias]], [[Patriarch of Antioch|Bishop of Antioch]] # [[Onesiphorus]], Bishop of [[Cyrene, Libya|Cyrene]] # [[Clement of Sardice|Clement]], Bishop of [[Sardis]] # [[Sosthenes]], Bishop of [[Colophon (city)|Colophon]] # [[Apollos]], Bishop of [[Caesarea]] # [[Tychicus]], Bishop of Colophon # [[Epaphroditus]] # [[Carpus of Beroea|Carpus]], Bishop of [[Veria|Beroea]] in [[Thrace]] # [[Quadratus of Athens|Quadratus]] # [[John Mark]] (commonly considered identical to [[Mark the Evangelist]]: see 4 above), bishop of Byblos{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/chr/bb/bb49.htm|title=The Book of the Bee, Chapter XLIX, The Names of the Apostles in Order|year=1886|accessdate=2008-02-21}} # [[Zenas the Lawyer]], Bishop of [[Lod|Diospolis]] # [[Aristarchus of Thessalonica|Aristarchus]], Bishop of [[Apamea (Syria)|Apamea]] in Syria # [[Saint Pudens|Pudens]] # [[Trophimus]] # [[Mark of Apollonias|Mark]], Bishop of Apollonia # [[Artemas of Lystra|Artemas]], Bishop of [[Lystra]] # [[Aquila (bible)|Aquila]] # [[Fortunatus the Apostle|Fortunatus]] # [[Achaicus of Corinth|Achaicus]] {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:17}} # [[Dorcas|Tabitha]], a woman disciple, whom Peter raised from the dead [[Saint Matthias|Matthias]], who would later replace [[Judas Iscariot]] as one of the twelve apostles, is also often numbered among the seventy, since John Mark is typically viewed as Mark the Evangelist.{{CathEncy|wstitle=St. Matthias}} Also, some lists name a few different disciples than the ones listed above. Other names commonly included are:{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} * Another Stephen * [[Rodion]] * [[Cephas of Iconium|Cephas]], Bishop of Iconium * [[Caesar of Dyrrhachium|Caesar]], Bishop of [[Dyrrhachium]] * Another [[Mark of Apollonias|Mark]], Bishop of [[Apollonias]] * Another [[Tychicus of Chalcedon|Tychicus]], [[Bishop of Chalcedon]] in Bithynia These are usually included at the expense of the aforementioned Timothy, Titus, Archippus, Crescens, Olympas, Epaphroditus, Quadratus, Aquila, Fortunatus, and/or Achaicus. [[Bishop]] Solomon of [[Basra]] of the [[Church of the East]] in the 13th century offers the following list: :''The names of the seventy''. # [[James the Just|James]], the son of Joseph; # [[Symeon of Jerusalem|Simon the son of Cleopas]]; # [[Cleopas]], his father; # [[Joses]]; # [[Simon (brother of Jesus)|Simon]]; # [[Jude, brother of Jesus|Judah]]; # Barnabas; # Manaeus (?); # [[Ananias of Damascus|Ananias]], who baptised Paul; # [[Aramaic of Jesus#Cephas|Cephas]], who preached at Antioch; # [[Joseph of Arimathea|Joseph the senator]]; # Nicodemus the archon; # Nathaniel the chief scribe; # [[Joseph Barsabbas|Justus, that is Joseph, who is called Barshabbâ]]; # Silas; # Judah; # John, surnamed Mark (John Mark); # [[Mnason]], who received Paul; # Manaël, the foster-brother of Herod; # [[Simeon Niger|Simon]] called Niger; # [[Jason of Thessalonica|Jason]], who is (mentioned) in the Acts (of the apostles); # [[Saints Rufus|Rufus]]; # Alexander; # [[Simon of Cyrene|Simon the Cyrenian, their father]]; # [[Lucius of Cyrene|Lucius the Cyrenian]]; # Another [[Judas Barsabbas|Judah]], who is mentioned in the Acts (of the apostles); # Judah, who is called Simon; # Eurion (Orion) the splay-footed; # Thôrus (?); # Thorîsus (?); # Zabdon; # Zakron.'' A more concise and acknowledged list{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} is below: # Archaicus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:17}} # Agabus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|11:28}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|21:10}} # Amplias, appointed by [[St. Andrew]] as bishop of [[Lod|Lydda]] of Odyssopolis (Diospolis) in [[Judea]]. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:8}}. # [[Ananias of Damascus|Ananias]], who baptized St. Paul. He was the bishop of Damascus. He became a martyr by being stoned in Eleutheropolis. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|9:10–17}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|22:12}} # Andronicus, bishop of Pannonia. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:7}} # Apelles, bishop of Heraclea (in Trachis). Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:10}} # Apollos. He was a bishop of several places over time: Crete (though this is questioned), Corinth, [[Smyrna]], and Caesarea. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|18:24}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|19:1}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|1:12}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|3:4–22}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|4:6}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:12}}, {{bibleref2|Titus|3:13}} # Aquila. He was martyred. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|18:2}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|18}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|26}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:3}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:19}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:19}} # Archippus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:17}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|2}} # Aristarchus, bishop of Apamea in Syria. He was martyred under [[Nero]]. “Aristarchus, whom [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] mentions several times, calling him a ‘fellow laborer,’ became bishop of Apamea in Syria.” [[Orthodox Study Bible]] Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|19:29}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|27:2}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:10}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|24}} # Aristobulus, bishop of Britain. “… the brother of the apostle Barnabas, preached the gospel in [[Great Britain]] and died peacefully there.” Orthodox Study Bible Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # Artemas, bishop of Lystra in Lycia. Reference to in Titus 3:12 # [[Aristarchus of Thessalonica|Aristarchus]], bishop of Hyracania in [[Asia]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # [[Barnabas]]. “A Jew of the Tribe of Levi, was born in [[Cyprus]] of wealthy parents. He is said to have studied under Gamaliel with Saul of [[Tarsus, Mersin|Tarsus]], who was to become Paul the apostle. Originally named Joseph, he was called Barnabas (Son of Consolation) by the apostles because he had a rare gift of comforting people’s hearts. He sought out Paul when everyone else was afraid of him, bringing him to the apostles. It was Barnabas whom the apostles first sent to [[Antioch]] with Paul. Their long association was broken only when Barnabas was determined to take his cousin Mark, whom Paul did not trust just then, on a missionary journey. The three were later reconciled. Many ancient accounts say Barnabas was the first to preach in [[Rome]] and in [[Milan]], but he was martyred in Cyprus, then buried by [[Mark the Evangelist|Mark]] at the western gate of the city of Salamis.” Orthodox Study Bible Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|4:36}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|9:27}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|11–15}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|9:6}}; {{bibleref2|Galatians|2:1, 9, 13}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:10}} # Caesar, bishop of Dyrrhachium (in the [[Peloponnese]] of [[Greece]]) # Carpus, bishop of Berroia (Verria, in Macedonia. Reference to in 2 Timothy 4:13 # Clement, bishop in Sardis. Reference to in Philippians 4:3 # Cephas, bishop of Iconium, Pamphyllia. # Cleopas, was with the Lord on the road to [[Emmaus]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Luke|24:18}}; {{bibleref2|John|19:25}} # Crescens, later bishop of [[Galatia]]. He was martyred under the Emperor Trajan. Reference to in 2 Timothy 4:10 # Crispus, bishop of [[Aegina]], Greece. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|18:8}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|1:14}} # Epaphras. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Colossians|1:7}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:12}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|23}} # Epaphroditus, bishop of the Thracian city of Adriaca. Reference to in Philippians 2:25; 4:18 # Epaenetus, bishop of Carthage. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:5}} # Erastus. He served as a deacon and steward to the Church of Jerusalem. Later he served in Palestine. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|19:22}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:23}}; 2 Timothy 4:20 # Euodias(Evodius), first bishop of Antioch after [[St.Peter]]. He wrote several compositions. At the age of sixty-six, under the Emperor Nero, he was martyred. Reference to in Philippians 4:2 # Fortunatus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|16:17}} # Gaius, bishop of Ephesus. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|19:29}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:23}}; {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|1:14}}; {{bibleref2|3 John|1}} # Hermas, bishop in Philipopoulis. He wrote ''The Shepherd of Hermas.'' He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # Hermes, bishop of Dalmatia. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # Herodion, a relative of the Apostle Paul, bishop of Neoparthia. He was beheaded in [[Rome]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:11}} # [[James the Just|James, brother of the Lord]] (also called "the Less" or "the Just"). James was the Patriarch of Jerusalem. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Matthew|13:55}}; {{bibleref2|Mark|6:3}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|12:17}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|15:13}}; [[Epistle of James]] # Jason, bishop of [[Tarsus, Mersin|Tarsus]]. Traveling with Sosipater to Corfu, the two were able, after an attempt made at their lives by the king of Corfu, to convert his majesty. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|17:5–9}} # Justus, brother to the Lord and bishop of Eleutheropolis. He was the half-brother of Christ (as was Sts. James, Jude, and Simon) through Joseph's previous marriage to Salome. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|1:23}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|18:7}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:11}} # Linus, bishop of Rome. Reference to in 2 Timothy 4:21 # Lucius, bishop of [[Laodicea on the Lycus|Laodicea]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|13:1}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:21}} # [[Luke the Evangelist]]. He is the author of the Gospel of Luke, and the founder of [[Iconography]] (Orthodox Icon-writing). Reference to in {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:14}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:11}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|24}} # [[Mark the Evangelist]] (called John). He wrote the Gospel of Mark. He also founded the Church of [[Alexandria]], serving as its first bishop. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|12:12}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|25}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|15:37–39}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:10}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:11}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|24}}; {{bibleref2|1 Peter|5:13}} # Mark # Narcissus, ordained by the Apostle Philip as bishop of [[Athens]], Greece. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:11}} # [[Nicanor the Deacon|Nicanor]], one of the original seven [[deacon]]s. He was martyred on the same day as the Promartyr Stephen. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # Olympas, beheaded with St. [[Saint Peter|Peter]] under Nero. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:15}} # Onesimus. Onesimus preached the Gospel in many cities. He was made bishop of Ephesus, and later bishop of [[Byzantium]] ([[Constantinople]]). He was martyred under the Emperor Trajan. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:9}}; {{bibleref2|Philemon|10}} # Onesiphorus, bishop of Colophon (Asia Minor), and later of Corinth. He died a martyr in Parium. Reference to in 2 Timothy 1:16; 4:19 # Parmenas, one of the original seven deacons. He preached throughout Asia Minor, and later settled in Macedonia. He was a bishop of Soli. He died a martyr in Macedonia. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # Patrobus, bishop of Neapolis ([[Naples]]). Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # [[Philemon (New Testament person)|Philemon]]. He, with his wife Apphia, and the apostle Archippus, were martyred by pagans during a pagan feast. Reference to in Philemon 1 # Philip the Deacon (one of the original seven). He was born in Palestine, and later preached throughout its adjoining lands. In Acts, he converts a eunuch (an official) of Candace, queen of Ethiopia, to Christ. He was later made bishop by the apostles at Jerusalem, who also sent him to Asia Minor. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|8}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|21:8}} # Philologus, ordained bishop of Sinope (near the [[Black sea]]) by the Apostle [[Saint Andrew|Andrew]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:15}} # Phlegon, bishop of [[Marathon]], in Thrace. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:14}} # Prochorus, one of the original seven deacons. He was made bishop of Nicomedia by [[St. Peter]]. He was later banished with the Apostle John ([[John the Theologian]]) to the Island of [[Patmos]]. In Antioch, he died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # Pudens (Pastorum). He was an esteemed member of the [[Roman Senate]], then received Sts. Peter and Paul into his home, and was converted to [[Christ]] by them. He was martyred under Nero. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # Quadratus, bishop of Athens. He was author of the ''Apologia''. He was stoned, but survived. Soon-after, he died of starvation in prison. # Quartus, bishop of [[Beirut]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:23}} # Rufus, bishop of [[Thebes, Greece|Thebes]], Greece. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Mark|15:21}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:13}} # Silas (Silvanus), bishop of Corinth. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|15:22–40}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|16:19–40}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|17:4–15}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|18:5}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|1:19}}; {{bibleref2|1 Thessalonians|1:1}}; {{bibleref2|2 Thessalonians|1:1}}; {{bibleref2|1 Peter|5:12}} # [[Simeon of Jerusalem|Simeon]], son of Cleopas. “Simeon, son of Cleopas (who was the brother of [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]], the betrothed of the [[Virgin Mary]]), succeeded James as [[Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem|bishop of Jerusalem]].” Orthodox Study Bible. He was martyred through torture and crucifixion, at the age of one-hundred. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Matthew|13:55}}; {{bibleref2|Mark|6:3}} # Sosipater, ordained bishop of Iconium by the Apostle [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]], his relative. With St. Jason, he converted the king of [[Corfu]]. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:21}} # Sosthenes. “… became bishop of Caesarea.” Orthodox Study Bible Reference to in {{bibleref2|1 Corinthians|1:1}} # Stachys, ordained by [[St. Andrew]] to be bishop of Byzantium. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:9}} # [[Saint Stephen|Stephen the Promartyr]] and Archdeacon (one of the original seven deacons). Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5–7:60}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|8:2}} ({{bibleref2|Acts|6:5–8:2}}); {{bibleref2|Acts|11:19}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|22:20}} # Tertius, bishop of Iconium (after Sosipater). He wrote down St. Paul's letter to the Romans. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:22}} # Thaddaeus. He was baptized by [[John the Baptist]] (John the Forerunner). He later preached, and founded a Church in Beirut. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Matthew|10:3}}; {{bibleref2|Mark|3:18}} # Timon, one of the original seven deacons, and later bishop of Bostra (in [[Arabia]]). He was thrown into a furnace, but emerged unharmed. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|6:5}} # [[Saint Timothy|Timothy]]. He accompanied [[St. Paul]] often, and both 1 and 2 Timothy are addressed to him. He was ordained bishop of Ephesus by St. Paul. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|16:1}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|17:14}}, {{bibleref2|Acts|15}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|18:5}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|19:22}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Romans|16:21}}; 1 and 2 Timothy # [[Saint Titus|Titus]]. “Among the more prominent of the seventy was the apostle Titus, whom [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] called his brother and his son. Born in Crete, Titus was educated in [[Greek philosophy]], but after reading the prophet [[Isaiah]] he began to doubt the value of all he had been taught. Hearing the news of the coming of [[Jesus Christ]], he joined some others from Crete who were going to [[Jerusalem]] to see for themselves. After hearing Jesus speak and seeing His works, the young Titus joined those who followed Him. Baptized by the apostle Paul, he worked with and served the great apostle of the [[gentiles]], traveling with him until Paul sent him to Crete, making him bishop of that city. It is said that Titus was in Rome at the time of the beheading of St. Paul and that he buried the body of his spiritual father before returning home. Back in Crete, he converted and baptized many people, governing the Church on that island until he entered into rest at the age of ninety-four.” Orthodox Study Bible Reference to in {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|2:13}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|7:6–14}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|8:6–23}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|12:18}}; {{bibleref2|Galatians|2:1–3}}; Epistle to Titus # Trophimus, disciple of [[St. Paul]], and martyred under Nero. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Acts|21:29}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:20}} # Tychicus. “… succeeded him (Sosthenes, as bishop) in that city (of Caesarea).” Orthodox Study Bible. He delivered St. Paul's letter to the Ephesians and Colossians. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Acts|20:4}}; {{bibleref2|Ephesians|6:21}}; {{bibleref2|Colossians|4:7}}; {{bibleref2|2 Timothy|4:12}}; {{bibleref2|Titus|3:12}} # Urbanus, ordained by the [[Apostle Andrew]] as bishop of [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]]. He died a martyr. Reference to in {{bibleref2|Romans|16:9}} # Zenas (called 'the lawyer'), bishop of Diospolis ([[Lod|Lydda]]), in [[Timeline of the name "Palestine"|Palestine]]. Reference to in Titus 3:13 Additional Names: # Alphaeus, father of the apostles James and Matthew. # Apphia, wife of the Apostle Philemon. The Church had gathered in her home for liturgy, while pagans who had been celebrating a pagan feast broke in and raided her home. They took Apphia, Philemon, and Archippus to be killed. She suffered martyrdom, and is commemorated by the Church on February 19. # Junia, accompanied Andronicus in preaching all over Pannonia. She was a relative to the Apostle Paul, and a martyr. # Silvan, bishop of [[Thessaloniki]], Greece. Reference to in {{bibleref2|1 Peter|5:12}}; {{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|1:19}} # [[Zacchaeus]], appointed by St. Peter to be bishop of Caesarea, referred to in {{bibleref2|Luke|19:1–10}} == Manuscripts of the New Testament with lists == * [[Minuscule 82]] * [[Minuscule 93]] * [[Minuscule 177]] * [[Minuscule 459]] * [[Minuscule 613]] * [[Minuscule 617]] * [[Minuscule 699]] == See also == {{portal|Christianity}} * [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament]] * [[Dispersion of the Apostles]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://orthodoxwiki.org/Seventy_Apostles Orthodoxwiki.org, ''Seventy Apostles''']. An overview of the lists made of the disciples/apostles with background on many of them. * [http://www-users.cs.york.ac.uk/~fisher/cgi-bin/gnt?id=0310 Luke 10 in Greek] * [http://bibledbdata.org/onlinebibles/greek_translit/42_010.htm Luke 10 in Greek transliterated] * [http://www.orthodox.net/saints/70apostles.html ''The Seventy Apostles''] * [http://www.sacred-texts.com/chr/bb/bb49.htm ''The Book of the Bee'', chapter XLIX "The names of the Apostles in order"] by Solomon, Nestorian bishop of Basra, 13th century (edited by Ernest A. Wallace Budge, 1886). * [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2008/06/080613-old-church.html ''"Oldest Church" in Rihad Jordan Discovery "Ridiculous," Critics Say''] {{New Testament people}} {{Catholic saints}} [[Category:Seventy disciples| ]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:Gospel episodes]] [[Category:Followers of Jesus]] [[Category:Christian missions]] [[Category:Christian terminology]] [[Category:Gospel of Luke]] [[Category:Lists of saints]] [[Category:Groups of Eastern Orthodox saints]]

revision.text:
[[File:Acro-cats.jpg|alt=A woman smiling and gesturing at two small orange cats, one seated on a cat and the other pushing the cart from behind|thumb|Two cats performing a cart pushing trick with the Amazing Acro-cat travelling cat circus.]] '''The Amazing Acro-cats''' is a [[circus]] troupe of domestic [[cat]]s and a few other small animals, founded by animal trainer Samantha Martin. One of the featured performers is the musical band, the '''Rock-Cats'''. The troupe is based in [[Chicago]],<ref name="Meet the Acro-Cats"/> and tours the [[United States]] for nine months of the year.<ref name="King 5"/>
==History== Founder Samantha Martin created the show in approximately 2005<ref name="kickstarter"/> as a way "''to keep her show cats mentally sharp in between television, film, and advertising jobs.''"<ref name="Seattle Stranger"/> In 2009, the troupe began to tour the U.S.<ref name="kickstarter"/> from its base in Chicago. In 2013, the troupe held its first show in Canada, in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]].<ref name="Canadian debut"/>
In 2012, Martin started a [[Kickstarter]] fundraiser to replace the aging RV that had been used as the tour bus.<ref name="kickstarter"/> A goal of the campaign was to upgrade the facility, providing "a lush, plush, safe, and stimulating environment for the cats; everything from built-in perches, posts, catwalks, and toys; and even a nursery for our foster kittens."<ref name="kickstarter"/> Over $30,500 was raised from 567 contributors, which exceeded the campaign goal by over $2,500.<ref name="kickstarter"/> A new bus was in place by February 2013.<ref name="Aspiring animal trainer"/>
==Use of clicker training==
Martin uses [[clicker training]] to teach domestic cats and other animals to perform tricks.<ref name="Brown Paper Tickets"/> A treat is given at the sound of a click at the exact moment the cats are doing a desired behavior.<ref name="Reporter-Herald"/> ''It's just more of a fine tuning way of training,'' Martin said. ''It's noise and treats. It triggers something in their brain, and they get it very quickly.''<ref name="Reporter-Herald"/>
Martin uses varieties of tuna and chicken to reward the cats.<ref name="King 5"/> The results are not as consistent as might be achieved with more compliant animals such as dogs,<ref name="Meow-y Christmas Review"/> but the "long-standing notion that cats are un-trainable is thrown completely out the window."<ref name="AXS"/> During the one-hour show, the cats perform tricks such as "''walking tightropes, pushing carts, skateboarding, jumping through hoops, ringing bells, balancing on balls and turning on lights.''"<ref name="Brown Paper Tickets"/> When the cats don't perform as planned, it adds an element of humour, an important part of the show.<ref name="Rochester Review"/>
==Promotion of cat welfare== Martin aims to improve the public perception of cats and to promote their welfare during her show. "We use our show as an entertaining demonstration of what cats are really capable of, as well as the healthy benefits of clicker training."<ref name="kickstarter"/> Martin demonstrates the [[clicker training]] technique in the show, training a kitten or cat to learn some new tricks.<ref name="Rochester Review"/> She explains that training can build richer relationships between cats and their humans;<ref name="Brown Paper Tickets"/> can be life-saving in emergencies when cats are trained to go to their carrier at the sound of a whistle;<ref name="Rochester Review"/> and can prevent behavioral problems, while providing physical exercise and mental stimulation.<ref name="kickstarter"/> "'We hope people are inspired to train their own cats,' Martin said. 'They enjoy the training. They want you to work with them.'"<ref name="Reporter-Herald"/> Clicker training kits are made available for purchase at shows and online.<ref>[http://shop.bewitchedcattoys.com/Acro-Cats-Merchandise_c9.htm "Acro-Cats Merchandise"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140901014358/http://shop.bewitchedcattoys.com/Acro-Cats-Merchandise_c9.htm |date=2014-09-01 }}, Bewitched Cat Toys, accessed July 27, 2014.</ref>
The cats in the troupe are mainly former orphans, rescues and strays.<ref name="kickstarter"/> Since about 2008, Martin has also fostered many homeless cats and kittens.<ref name="kickstarter"/> She brings her fosters on tour, training them and featuring them in the show. Over the years, over 140 foster cats or kittens have been adopted to new homes as a result of these efforts.<ref name="Reporter-Herald"/> A portion of show proceeds is typically given to cat rescue organizations,<ref name="Brown Paper Tickets"/><ref name="AXS"/> and on occasion the show itself is a benefit to promote a rescue organization.<ref name="Reporter-Herald"/>
==The Rock-Cats== Each show closes with a performance by the Rock-Cats, billed as the "''only cat band in existence''".<ref name="Seattle Stranger"/> A review of a [[Seattle]] show in 2014 said "these cats are capable of anarchic musical compositions" that Martin likens to [[free jazz]]; "''an unpredictable assortment of instrument clanging, and rarely does it sound like the cats are playing the same song, let alone an actual, fully realized piece of music.''"<ref name="Seattle Stranger"/> Nevertheless, the reviewer found that "''white-haired diva''" band leader Tuna "''has the perfect demeanor for a rock star of any species.''"<ref name="Seattle Stranger"/> Another reviewer of the Seattle show said it was a "really, really fun way to spend an afternoon", and listened politely to the band while realizing that Oz was a better guitar player than she was.<ref name="Back Beat Seattle review"/>
A reviewer of a 2013 show in [[New Orleans]] was critical of the band's musicality, and complained that the advertised "seasonal carol selections such as 'A Cat in a Manger' and 'Catnip Roasting on an Open Fire'" never materialized."<ref name="Meow-y Christmas Review"/> A review of a [[Los Angeles]] show in 2012 stated that although the band was unlikely to win any [[Grammy Award]]s anytime soon, "''what they lacked in technical skill, they certainly made up for in rock 'n' roll catitude''".<ref name="Meow Remix"/>
===Band members=== *Oz, a male green-eyed tabby [[domestic short-haired cat]] born in 2005, plays guitar.<ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/oz.html "Oz"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref> *Nola, a female blue-eyed, mainly white [[domestic short-haired cat]] with grey [[Siamese cat|siamese]] [[Tabby cat|tabby]] markings, born in 2014, also plays guitar.<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/pages/Tuna-and-The-Rock-cats/84494939571 Tuna and the Rock Cats Facebook Page], September 1, 2014, update.</ref> *Dakota, a female white haired [[Turkish Angora]] cat with a tiny black mohawk, born in 2005, is the main drummer.<ref>[http://circuscats.com/dakotaacro.html "Dakota 'The Diva'"], The Acro-Cats, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/dakota.html "Dakota"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref> *Fiji, a female white and grey [[Himalayan cat|Himalayan]] cat born in 2007, is a back-up drummer.<ref>[http://www.circuscats.com/fijiacro.html "Meet Fiji: The Princess"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/fiji.html Fiji], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref> *Asti, a female golden-eyed tabby [[domestic short-haired cat]] born in 2010, is in training for drums.<ref>[http://www.circuscats.com/astiacro.html "Asti 'The Sneak'"], The Acro-Cats, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/asti.html "Asti"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref> *Nue, a female blue-eyed tabby [[domestic short-haired cat]] born in 2005, is on keyboards.<ref>[http://www.circuscats.com/nueacro.html "Nue 'The Flirt'"], The Acro-Cats, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/nue.html "Nue"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref> *Sookie, a female [[tortoiseshell cat|tortoiseshell]] [[domestic short-haired cat]] born in 2009, is on chimes.<ref>[http://www.circuscats.com/sookieacro.html "Sookie 'The Airhead'"], The Acro-Cats, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/sookie.html "Sookie"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref> *Cluck Norris, a chicken, plays cymbal and tambourine.<ref name="Brown Paper Tickets"/> *Garfield, a groundhog, works a gong or cymbals.<ref name="Back Beat Seattle review"/>
===Former band members=== *Pinky, a female white [[domestic short-haired cat]], was a "''focussed, professional and very demanding''" guitar player, who died of breast cancer in August 2012.<ref>[http://www.circuscats.com/pinkyrock.html "Pinky 'The Artist'"], The Acro-Cats, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref> *Hendiana Jones, a chicken with a knack for peace-keeping, last appeared in 2012.<ref name="Meow Remix"/> *Tuna, a female white [[domestic short-haired cat]] born in 2002, was the band leader and played a cowbell. Tuna died in January 2017 of cancer.<ref name="Tuna the star"/><ref name="Tuna"/><ref>[http://www.icflorida.com/news/tuna-star-of-the-amazing-acrocats-dies-of-cancer/484452107 Tuna, star of the Amazing Acro-Cats, dies of cancer], icflorida.com, accessed January 14, 2017.</ref>
==Agile cats== The circus performances involve demonstrations of feline agility. In 2014, Alley, a [[calico cat|calico]] [[domestic short-haired cat]], broke the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] for the longest jump by a domestic cat at six feet or 182.88 cm.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/guinness-world-records-60th-anniversary-new-records-include-the-worlds-longest-usable-golf-club-and-the-cat-with-the-biggest-leap-9722749.html "Guinness World Records 60th anniversary: New records include the world's longest usable golf club and the cat with the biggest leap"], Karen Moodley, The Independent, Sept. 10, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.lifewithcats.tv/2014/09/10/2-alley-the-cat-sets-guinness-record-for-longest-cat-jump/ "Alley the Cat Sets Guinness Record For Longest Cat Jump"], Karen Harrison Binette, Live with Cats, Sept. 10, 2014.</ref>
==Actor cats== Martin maintains her long-standing business<ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/about.html "About us"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 28, 2014.</ref> Samantha's Amazing Animals, where she showcases cats and other animals for hire in television, film and advertising jobs.<ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/index.html Samantha's Amazing Animals], accessed August 28, 2014.</ref> Twenty-nine domestic cats and an African [[serval]] were listed for hire in 2014, each with their own profile.<ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/cats.html "Cat Stars"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 28, 2014.</ref>
Tuna starred as a killer cat in the award-winning 2004 short film ''Zeke''.<ref>[http://vimeo.com/8042668 "Zeke"], Matt Olmon, Vimeo, accessed August 28, 2014.</ref> She also starred in a film ''Cat House'' and had a smaller role in the film ''Ophelia''.<ref name="Tuna"/> On television, she competed in the [[Animal Planet]] program [[Pet Star]], was featured in the [[Animal Planet]] program ''Animal Witness'', has appeared in a [[Comedy Central]] pilot television program, and was the main cat in the television program ''Mama Said''.<ref name="Tuna"/> Tuna has also worked in advertising since she was a six-week-old kitten.<ref name="Tuna the star"/>
Buggles, a female mainly black tabby [[domestic short-haired cat]] born in 2007, has appeared in the independent film ''South Dakota'' and an international film, ''God's Smile''.<ref>[http://circuscats.com/bugglesacro.html "Meet Buggles: The Nerd"], The Acro-Cats, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.amazinganimals.biz/buggles.html "Buggles"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref>
==See also== *[[Clicker training]] *[[Cat training]]
==Further reading== *"''Tuna: Kitty Rock Star''", pp. 68-100, Aline Alexander Newman, ''Animal Superstars: And More True Stories of Amazing Animal Talents'' (2013, [[National Geographic Society]]), {{ISBN|9781426310911}} (paperback), {{ISBN|9781426310928}} (reinforced library edition) (Children, non-fiction).
==References== {{Reflist|2 |refs= <ref name="kickstarter"> [https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/tunaandtherockcats/amazing-acro-cats-and-rock-cats-purr-fect-tour-bus "Amazing Acro-Cats and Rock-Cats Purr-fect Tour Bus"], Kickstarter, project successfully funded on October 28, 2012.</ref>
<ref name="Meet the Acro-Cats"> [http://circuscats.com/acrocats.html#.U_6rXYCwIfE "Meet the Acro-Cats"], The Acro-Cats, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref>
<ref name="Aspiring animal trainer"> [https://www.facebook.com/84494939571/photos/pb.84494939571.-2207520000.1406514481./10151768240654572/?type=3&theater "Aspiring animal trainer/experienced animal caretaker to travel the country with a troupe of trained cats"], Facebook status update of "Tuna and the 'Rock-Cats'" included a photo of the new bus, February 4, 2013.</ref>
<ref name="Seattle Stranger"> [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/the-amazing-acro-cats-return-to-seattle/Content?oid=19830931 "The Amazing Acro-Cats Return to Seattle"], Jackson Hathorn, The Stranger, June 11, 2014.</ref>
<ref name="Back Beat Seattle review"> [http://backbeatseattle.com/2014/07/14/show-review-photos-the-amazing-acro-cats-seattle-center/ "Show Review & Photos: The Amazing Acro-Cats @ Seattle Center"], Dana Easterling, Back Beat Seattle, 6/21/14.</ref>
<ref name="Canadian debut"> [http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1207699/the-amazing-acro-cats-rock-cats-are-coming-to-canada "The Amazing Acro-Cats & Rock Cats are Coming to Canada!"], CNW, Aug. 7, 2013.</ref>
<ref name="Brown Paper Tickets"> [http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/644013 "The Amazing Acrocats Wow Seattle Washington!"], Brown Paper Tickets, June 12-22, 2014 events.</ref>
<ref name="Reporter-Herald"> [http://www.reporterherald.com/loveland-other-events/ci_26127811/amazing-acro-cats-perform-fundraiser-loveland-cat-adoption "Amazing Acro-Cats to perform in fundraiser for Loveland Cat Adoption & Resource Center"], Shelley Widhalm, Reporter-Herald, 7/10/2014.</ref>
<ref name="King 5"> [http://www.king5.com/on-tv/evening-magazine/A-Real-Cat-Show-from-the-Amazing-Acro-Cats-264459101.html "A Real Cat Show from the Amazing Acro Cats!"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701102524/http://www.king5.com/on-tv/evening-magazine/A-Real-Cat-Show-from-the-Amazing-Acro-Cats-264459101.html |date=2014-07-01 }}, Anne Erickson, Evening Magazine, King 5, June 24, 2014.</ref>
<ref name="AXS"> [http://www.axs.com/the-amazing-acro-cats-cat-circus-is-coming-to-town-14755 "The Amazing Acro-Cats cat circus is coming to town"], Deb Flomberg, AXS, July 18, 2014.</ref>
<ref name="Meow-y Christmas Review"> [http://www.bestofneworleans.com/blogofneworleans/archives/2013/12/07/review-the-amazing-acro-cats-in-a-very-meow-y-christmas "Review: The Amazing Acro-Cats in A Very Meow-y Christmas"], Kevin Allman, Blog of New Orleans, Dec. 7, 2013.</ref>
<ref name="Rochester Review"> [http://www.rochestercitynewspaper.com/EntertainmentBlog/archives/2013/08/07/review-the-amazing-acro-cats-at-muccc-through-811 "Review: The Amazing Acro-cats at MuCCC (through 8/11)"], City Newspaper Entertainment Blog, Rochester City News, Aug 7, 2013.</ref>
<ref name="Meow Remix"> [https://music.yahoo.com/blogs/live/meow-remix-meet-rock-cats-world-only-feline-015542680.html "Meow Remix! Meet The Rock-Cats, The World’s Only All-Feline Band"], Lindsey Parker, Yahoo Music, February 28, 2012.</ref>
<ref name="Tuna the star"> [http://www.circuscats.com/tunaacro.html "Tuna 'The Star'"], The Acro-Cats, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref>
<ref name="Tuna"> [http://www.amazinganimals.biz/tuna.html "Tuna"], Samantha's Amazing Animals, accessed August 27, 2014.</ref> }}
